Which of the following statements is most likely to be challenged by the above argument? 1) The argument unreflectively excludes humans from nature. 2) The evidence presented applies equally to both alternative hypotheses: Climate change caused the extinction of large mammals, the same reasons that brought humans to all parts of North America. 3) The extinction of large mammals such as mastodons, mammoths and saber-toothed tiger was of extraordinary significance to the hominids of early North America. 4) The arrival of humans in North America may have led to the extinction of other animals besides mastodons, mammoths and saber-toothed tiger.
answer: 4: The evidence presented applies equally to both alternative hypotheses: Climate change caused the extinction of large mammals, the same reasons that brought humans to all parts of North America.

question: Linda: During the summer months, people normally take vacations. Ttherefore, during the summer months, the local economy suffers since local residents spend their money at their vacation destinations. Billy: Why do you think that the local economy would be suffering? During the summer months, tourists who come to our city actually spend lots of money at local businesses, attractions, and restaurants. Which of the following most correctly explains how Billy's reply is related to Linda's argument? 1) The reply shows that Linda fails to realize that people often are forced by their employers to take their vacations in the summer. 2) The reply offers another reason why the local economy suffers during the summer months that is unrelated to vacations. 3) The reply argues that Linda's conclusion is correct, but not because of the reasons that Linda claims. 4) The reply offers an additional factor to consider that weakens Linda's conclusion.
answer: 4: The reply offers an additional factor to consider that weakens Linda's conclusion.

question: Robust crops not only withstand insect attacks more successfully than other crops, they are also less likely to be attacked in the first place, since insects tend to feed on weaker plants. Killing insects with pesticides does not address the underlying problem of inherent vulnerability to damage caused by insect attacks. Thus, a better way to reduce the vulnerability of agricultural crops to insect pest damage is to grow those crops in good soil -- soil with adequate nutrients, organic matter, and microbial activity. Which one of the following is an assumption on which the argument depends? 1) The application of nutrients and organic matter to farmland improves the soil's microbial activity. 2) Crops that are grown in good soil tend to be more robust than other crops. 3) Growing crops without the use of pesticides generally produces less robust plants than when pesticides are used. 4) The application of pesticides to weak crops fails to reduce the extent to which they are damaged by insect pests.
answer: 3: Crops that are grown in good soil tend to be more robust than other crops.

question: If newly hatched tobacco hornworms in nature first feed on plants from the nightshade family, they will not eat leaves from any other plants thereafter. However, tobacco hornworms will feed on other sorts of plants if they feed on plants other than nightshades just after hatching. To explain this behavior, scientists hypothesize that when a hornworm' s first meal is from a nightshade, its taste receptors become habituated to the chemical indioside D, which is found only in nightshades, and after this habituation nothing without indioside D tastes good. Which one of the following, if true, adds the most support for the hypothesis? 1) Indioside D is not the only chemical that occurs only in nightshade plants. 2) Tobacco hornworm eggs are most commonly laid on nightshade plants. 3) If taste receptors are removed from tobacco hornworms that first fed on nightshade leaves, those hornworms will subsequently feed on other leaves. 4) Tobacco hornworms that first fed on nightshade leaves show no preference for any one variety of nightshade plant over any other.
answer: 4: If taste receptors are removed from tobacco hornworms that first fed on nightshade leaves, those hornworms will subsequently feed on other leaves.

question: Historically, monetary systems have developed only in population centers with marketplaces. Through the fourth century B. C. , Mesopotamian cities engaged in trade, but had never had marketplaces. By that period, however, Greek cities all had marketplaces, or agorae. The Greek cities' agorae were centrally located and goods were traded there either for money or for commodities. If all of the statements in the passage are true, then which one of the following must also be true? 1) The development of monetary systems has historically led to the development of marketplaces. 2) The Mesopotamian cities of the fourth century B. C. did not have monetary systems. 3) In the fourth century B. C. , Greek cities were the only population centers with monetary systems. 4) In the fourth century B. C. , the Greeks and the Mesopotamians traded with each other.
answer: 2: The Mesopotamian cities of the fourth century B. C. did not have monetary systems.

question: In its search for new technologies for solar energy that can produce lower-cost electricity, Smith-Diatom is developing a new way to make dye-sensitive solar cells, in which photons strike light-sensitive dyes. The process uses diatoms, which are unicellular algae that have silicon shells with a complex structure. First, the organic material is removed, and then the shells are coated with a titanium dioxide film that acts as a semiconductor. The diatoms' structure results in more photon activity and thus more efficient production of electricity than with current dye-sensitized solar cells, which in turn lowers the cost. Which of the following considerations would, if true, most strongly support the hypothesis that the plan, if implemented, will produce low-cost electricity from dye-sensitive solar cells? 1) The production of dye-sensitive solar cells primarily uses materials that do not harm the environment. 2) Because diatoms occur naturally, no special engineering processes are needed to produce the basic dye-sensitive solar cell structures. 3) Dye-sensitive solar cells work somewhat more efficiently in lower light than previous solar cell technologies. 4) Diatoms are an important link in oceanic food chains and help cycle carbon dioxide from the atmosphere.
answer: 2: Because diatoms occur naturally, no special engineering processes are needed to produce the basic dye-sensitive solar cell structures.

question: Fever is a common symptom in children. There are often such children in clinical practice. Low fever usually lasts for a while after the fever subsides, but the physical signs and laboratory parameters are normal. At the same time, there was no obvious discomfort and the child's mental status was good. Western medicine has no specific treatment. In addition, some patients have fever of unknown cause, which often lasts for 1 ~ 2 months. As a result, these children often seek treatment in traditional Chinese medicine. Which of the following options from this text can be inferred? 1) The effect of traditional Chinese medicine on persistent fever in children is better. 2) Western medicine is very useful for children with persistent fever. 3) There is a secret formula for treating persistent fever in children with traditional chinese medicine. 4) There is no specific treatment for persistent fever in children.
answer: 3: The effect of traditional Chinese medicine on persistent fever in children is better.

question: Under the new normal, consumer demand has undergone profound changes, consumption has been upgraded, and personalized and diversified consumption has gradually become the mainstream. For a considerable number of consumers, the pursuit of product quality overwhelms the consideration of price. Supply-side structural reforms, in the final analysis, meet demand. Low-quality production capacity will inevitably be surplus, and production capacity that is constantly updated to meet market demand will not be surplus. Based on the above statement, which of the following can be derived? 1) Only products that are constantly updated can meet the needs of individualized and diversified consumption. 2) Low-quality production capacity cannot meet individual needs. 3) The production capacity that is constantly updated to meet market demand is not a low-quality production capacity. 4) Only high-quality and high-priced products can meet demand.
answer: 1: The production capacity that is constantly updated to meet market demand is not a low-quality production capacity.

question: In 1998, archaeologists found a forty-million-year-old baby bird frozen in amber. Although the sample was not large enough to determine its flying habits at such a young age, scientists guessed that the three-day-old bird would have been able to fly from birth and might have been hunting at the time the tree sap fell onto the bird, preserving it for millions of years. This proves how different this species of birds is from modern birds; modern birds depend on their parents for care for 2 to 3 weeks, while this ancient specimen was able to hunt right out of the nest. The reasoning in the argument is most vulnerable to criticism on the grounds that the argument 1) does not consider the possibility that immediate flight was a risk to the species. 2) draws its conclusion from data that cannot be proven true. 3) takes an inconsistent stance regarding its premise and conclusion. 4) confuses the cause of death with the effects of death.
answer: 2: draws its conclusion from data that cannot be proven true.

question: Business tax is a tax levied on business income from the provision of taxable services, the transfer of intangible assets, or the sale of immovable properties within the territory of China. It occurs in the process of production, operation, consumption, and circulation, and is a turnover tax levied on income for the operation of goods obtained, non-commodity services. Which one of the followings is not required to pay business tax? 1) Real estate companies buy and sell real estate 2) Operating income of a dance hall 3) Teachers issue graduation certificates to students at the cost of production 4) A large supermarket
answer: 4: Teachers issue graduation certificates to students at the cost of production

question: Some educators have had remarkable success with an unusual approach to science education. For example, a physics lesson on the properties of waves might begin by plucking guitar strings. After observing the strings vibrate, students would begin to apply names to the phenomena they had witnessed, such as frequency and amplitude. Only after fully understanding these real-life concepts would they begin to apply abstract terms and equations to the phenomena. Which one of the following principles is best illustrated by the example above? 1) Students learn best when teachers appeal to the interests of their students. 2) Students are unable to form abstract concepts concerning phenomena until they become familiar with these phenomena. 3) Familiarity with phenomena facilitates the learning of more formal treatments of these phenomena. 4) Students will understand abstract terms only if they are applicable to phenomena they have observed.
answer: 1: Familiarity with phenomena facilitates the learning of more formal treatments of these phenomena.

question: They believed that they should not be entangled in the old accounts between China and Japan, but should look at the great interests of China Japan friendship. Some outstanding representatives of them also put forward a new thinking theory on China Japan relations according to the model of the European economic community. They believed that if the greater East Asia co prosperity circle designed by Japan as early as the 20th century would bring great blessings to the Asian people. It can be inferred that the author's attitude is: 1) Unsettled 2) Yes and no 3) No 4) Yes

In order to communicate successfully, we need to refer to the reference systems in which the world is compatible. But we can not all have the same experience, so an identical frame of reference is impossible. Which of the following best supports the above reasoning? 1) Exactly the same reference system must rely on the same experience. 2) Successful communication is impossible. 3) The exact same reference system must be compatible. 4) Different experiences create an incompatible world.
answer: 2: Exactly the same reference system must rely on the same experience.

question: According to the price, the contract can be divided into open contract and closed contract. The opening price refers to the price that can only be determined through calculation according to a certain pricing method, and the closed price refers to the price that has been determined at the time of the conclusion of the contract. A sale contract without a fixed price is an open contract. According to the above definition, which of the following options belongs to the open contract? 1) When Mr. Fang and his wife divorced, they agreed that the daughter would be raised by the woman, and Mr. Fang would pay the woman a monthly maintenance fee of 2000 yuan until the child reached adulthood. If the child has additional expenses such as illness, the expenses shall be decided by both parties through consultation. 2) Company A and Company B sign a supply contract and agree on the unit price of the supply. Company A places the order for the second month to Company B every month, and the settlement is made according to the quantity of Company A's storage at the end of the month. If the price fluctuation of the raw material market exceeds the price of this contract by more than 10%, it can be negotiated again. 3) Aunt Jiang is very old. With the consent of Aunt Jiang, her three sons agreed to transfer the two-bedroom in her name to the eldest son, while the other sons gave up their requirements for the property and let the eldest son take care of Aunt Jiang and take care of all the expenses. 4) Mr. Li signed a contract with the decoration company, agreeing that the total price for decoration is 120000. When checking out, the decoration company proposed that Mr. Li asked to use higher standard hardware in the decoration process, so he asked Mr. Li to pay an extra 2000 yuan.
answer: 2: Company A and Company B sign a supply contract and agree on the unit price of the supply. Company A places the order for the second month to Company B every month, and the settlement is made according to the quantity of Company A's storage at the end of the month. If the price fluctuation of the raw material market exceeds the price of this contract by more than 10%, it can be negotiated again.

question: The opposite theory of the investment market refers to the fact that the investment market itself does not create new value, does not increase value and can even be said to be impairment. If an investor is the same as most investors when investing, then he must not make the most profit, because It is impossible for the majority to profit. In order to get the maximum benefit, it must be inconsistent with the actions of the majority of people. According to the above definition, which of the following options does not conform to the opposite theory of the investment market? 1) When the market is full of investors, we will leave the market again 2) It has fallen so much, it's time to go to the end 3) When many people are afraid, it is an opportunity for us and we have to be careful when many people are greedy 4) As long as you disagree with most investors, the opportunity to get rich will always exist
answer: 3: It has fallen so much, it's time to go to the end

question: Computer manufacturers have sought to make computer chips ever smaller, since decreasing the size of a computer' s central processing unit (CPU) chip -- without making that CPU chip any less sophisticated -- will proportionally increase the speed of the CPU chip and the computer containing it. But since CPU chips cannot be made significantly smaller without decreasing their sophistication, computers cannot currently be made significantly faster. Which one of the following is an assumption on which the argument depends? 1) Computers cannot currently be made faster unless their CPU chips are made smaller. 2) If both the size and the sophistication of a CPU chip are decreased, the speed of that chip will decrease. 3) Few, if any, computer manufacturers believe that computers can be made significantly faster. 4) Even if CPU chips are made slightly less sophisticated, they cannot currently be made much smaller.
answer: 3: Computers cannot currently be made faster unless their CPU chips are made smaller.

question: After several attempts to distract his young parrot from chewing on furniture, George reluctantly took an expert' s advice and gently hit the parrot' s beak whenever the bird started to chew furniture. The bird stopped chewing furniture, but it is now afraid of hands and will sometimes bite. Since chewing on the furniture would not have hurt the bird, George should not have hit it. When Carla' s puppy escaped from her yard, it bounded into a busy street. Although Carla does not generally approve of physical discipline, she hit the puppy sharply with her hand. Now the puppy enters the street only when accompanied by Carla, so Carla was justified in disciplining the puppy. Which one of the following principles, if established, would justify the judgments about George's and Carla's actions? 1) Using physical discipline to train an animal is justified only when all alternative strategies for correcting undesirable behavior have failed. 2) When training an animal, physical discipline should be used only when such discipline is necessary to correct behavior that could result in serious harm to the animal. 3) Physical discipline should not be used by an animal trainer except to correct persistent behavior problems. 4) When disciplining an animal physically, a trainer should use an object such as a rolled up newspaper to avoid making the animal frightened of hands.
answer: 3: When training an animal, physical discipline should be used only when such discipline is necessary to correct behavior that could result in serious harm to the animal.

question: In the next decade, a large percentage of municipalities throughout the country will experience power failures if they do not modernize their electrical substations. The vast majority of substations in the country already handle currents between 60% and 80% of their maximum capacity, and currents are expected to rise, perhaps by as much as a factor of 3 in the next decade, because of population increase and the increased demand from both industry and electronics in individual homes. Which of the following is an assumption of the above argument? 1) An electrical substation fails when the current it handles rises above its maximum capacity. 2) Ten years from now, the average household will own a greater number of electronic devices than does the average household today. 3) A modernized electric substation would be able to handle at least three times the amount of current as does a current substation. 4) Many electrical substations in operation today are old, and have several aged components that could break down, leading to power failures, even if current levels don't increase substantially.
answer: 1: An electrical substation fails when the current it handles rises above its maximum capacity.

question: In the past 50 years, the average life expectancy of the registered population in The city has increased by 38 years to 82 years, ranking the highest in China. At the same time, the overall morbidity and mortality rate of malignant tumors in the city also increased year by year, and has been equivalent to 2/3--3/4 of the developed countries and regions in Europe and the United States. In the world at a medium level, in the country at a high level. Which of the following options can be inferred? 1) The overall morbidity and mortality rate of malignant tumors in the city is actually lower than that of developed countries and regions in Europe and the United States. 2) The city currently has the highest level of treatment for malignant tumors in the country. 3) The overall morbidity and mortality rate of malignant neoplasms in the city is increasing year by year, but such diseases are not the main cause of death in the city at present. 4) If the incidence of the major diseases that killed the population of the city 50 years ago has not decreased at present, then the level of treatment for those diseases must have improved over the past 50 years.
answer: 2: The overall morbidity and mortality rate of malignant tumors in the city is actually lower than that of developed countries and regions in Europe and the United States.

question: A, B, C and D are suspected of a case. A said: the perpetrator is B. B said: the perpetrator is a. C said: the perpetrator is not me. D said: the perpetrator is among the four of us. If only one of the four people speaks the truth, which of the following is true? 1) The perpetrator is B. 2) The perpetrator is A. 3) The conditions in the question stem are not enough to determine who is the perpetrator. 4) The perpetrator is C.
answer: 4: The conditions in the question stem are not enough to determine who is the perpetrator.

question: Professor: Unfortunately, pharmaceutical companies and other profit-driven institutions provide nearly all of the funding for the chemistry department' s research. Moreover, unless we can secure more funding for basic science research, it is highly unlikely that any significant advances in basic research will come out of the department. Thus, without increased funding from sources other than profit-driven institutions, the chemistry department is unlikely to gain the prestige that only achievements in basic science research confer. Which one of the following is an assumption on which the professor's argument relies? 1) If the chemistry department's prestige increases substantially, then it is highly likely that the department's funding from sources other than profit-driven institutions will subsequently increase. 2) The profit-driven institutions that currently provide almost all of the chemistry department's funding are not likely to benefit from basic scientific research. 3) Members of the chemistry department are unlikely to make significant advances in basic science research if the department does not forego the funding it currently receives from profit-driven institutions. 4) The chemistry department's funding for basic science research is not likely to increase if its funding from sources other than profit-driven institutions does not increase.
answer: 2: The chemistry department's funding for basic science research is not likely to increase if its funding from sources other than profit-driven institutions does not increase.

question: Some people think that the underhand throw in baseball is not dangerous. But in 1920, the pitching method should be banned after Carl's underhand hit Chapman, who died of a head injury. Which of the following forms does the above reasoning process conform to? 1) Apply a general principle to a particular example. 2) Confuse the cause with the effect. 3) The advocate was attacked for personal rather than logical reasons. 4) Draw a general conclusion from a particular case.
answer: 3: Draw a general conclusion from a particular case.

question: In Zululan, South Africa, a rhino is poached every 17 hours. The Operation of the Flying Rhino carefully selected 114 white rhinos and 10 black rhinos from the Umm Floch Reserve and airlifted them to a secret area in South Africa to protect the rhinos in the hope that the rhinos can reproduce and grow here naturally in order to avoid the extinction of rhinos caused by poaching. Which of the following options is not the assumption of the flying rhino ? 1) The secrecy of the new home of the rhino is tight, because poachers don't know where there are rhinos. 2) A protective transfer operation to avoid the extinction of black rhinos 60 years ago was successful. 3) It is believed that the new home chosen by the rhino is suitable for the reproduction and growth of white rhinoceros and black rhinos. 4) Residents living near the new home of the rhino will not poach for the feet of expensive rhinos.
answer: 4: A protective transfer operation to avoid the extinction of black rhinos 60 years ago was successful.

question: Leona: If the average consumption of eggs in the United States were cut in half, an estimated 5, 000 lives might be saved each year. Thomas: How can that be? That would mean that if people adopt this single change in diet for ten years, the population ten years from now will be greater by 50, 000 people than it otherwise would have been. Which one of the following is a statement that Leona could offer Thomas to clarify her own claim and to address the point he has made? 1) The actual rate of population growth depends not only on the birth rate, but also on changes in life expectancy. 2) It is accurate to say that 5, 000 lives have been saved as long as 5, 000 people who would have died in a given year as a result of not changing their diet, did not do so -- even if they died for some other reason. 3) If egg consumption were reduced by more than half, the estimated number of lives saved each year could be even more than 5, 000. 4) For the average consumption of eggs to be cut by half, many individual consumers would have to cut their own consumption by much more than half.
answer: 1: It is accurate to say that 5, 000 lives have been saved as long as 5, 000 people who would have died in a given year as a result of not changing their diet, did not do so -- even if they died for some other reason.

question: You should not praise an act of apparent generosity unless you believe it is actually performed out of selfless motives, and you should not condemn an act of apparent selfishness unless you believe it is actually performed out of self-centered motives. Which one of the following judgments conforms to the principle stated above? 1) Caroline rightly blamed her coworker Monica for failing to assist her in doing a time-consuming project, even though she knew that Monica had offered to help in the project earlier but that her offer had been vetoed by their supervisor. 2) It was correct for Sarah not to praise Michael for being charitable when he told her that he donates a tenth of his income to charity, since she guessed that he only told that fact in order to impress her. 3) Daniel was right not to praise Margaret for offering to share her house with a visiting French family, since he believed that she made the offer only because she hoped it would be reciprocated by an invitation to use the family's apartment in Paris. 4) Albert correctly criticized Louise for adopting an abandoned dog because he believed that, although she felt sorry for the dog, she did not have sufficient time or space to care for it adequately.
answer: 3: Daniel was right not to praise Margaret for offering to share her house with a visiting French family, since he believed that she made the offer only because she hoped it would be reciprocated by an invitation to use the family's apartment in Paris.

question: Social behavior pattern refers to the behavior pattern jointly created, recognized or observed by most members of society. As a result of people's social communication, once the social behavior pattern is formed, it has repeatability, stability and regularity, coexists with groups, and is expressed by individual specific behavior. According to the above definition, which of the following is not a social behavior pattern? 1) Respect the old and cherish the young. 2) Work at sunrise and rest at sunset. 3) Men tilling the farm and women weaving. 4) Better to die with honor than to survive in disgrace.
answer: 4: Better to die with honor than to survive in disgrace.

question: Zhang Qiang: The 'face-changing' stunt in Sichuan Opera has been privately taught to foreign countries by individual actors, and has now spread to Japan, Singapore, Germany and other places. The main artistic value of Sichuan Opera lies in face-changing, and revealing the secret of face-changing is equivalent to ruining the artistic life of Sichuan Opera. Li Ming: Even if foreigners learn to change their faces, it will not affect the survival and value of the traditional art of Sichuan Opera. The intangible cultural heritage can only be inherited and developed when it opens its doors, goes to the public, and integrates into modern life. Which of the followings, if true, best supports Li Ming's point of view? 1) Foreigners learn Sichuan Opera because of their admiration for the art of face-changing, which will promote the spread of Sichuan Opera and encourage Sichuan Opera to create new stunts. 2) Many foreigners learn to perform Peking Opera, but this does not harm the image of Peking Opera as the quintessence of China. 3) The result of the rumors about face-changing technology is that the art of Sichuan Opera has changed. 4) In 1987, the Ministry of Culture listed Sichuan Opera's face-changing art as a second-level state secret, which is the only state secret in the Chinese theater industry.
answer: 1: Foreigners learn Sichuan Opera because of their admiration for the art of face-changing, which will promote the spread of Sichuan Opera and encourage Sichuan Opera to create new stunts.

question: Jake works for Bank Conglomerate of America (BCA), the largest investment bank in the United States. Jake has worked at Bank Conglomerate of America for a decade. Every American investment bank employs dozens of lawyers to defend against insider-trading allegations. Some Bank Conglomerate of America employees must pass a certification course. However, all employees must complete a mandatory class on insider trading. If the statements above are correct, which of the following must not be true? 1) Jake never took a class on insider trading. 2) Jake took a class on insider trading. 3) Jake passed a certification course. 4) Jake has worked at Bank Conglomerate of America for a decade.
answer: 3: Jake never took a class on insider trading.

question: On March 2, 2010, five college students admitted through various examinations in Jinan took up their posts. These five college students were admitted among nearly 400 candidates. After nearly half a year's training and environmental adaptation, they became real shit-scooper. Which of the following is the Enlightenment of this incident? 1) As long as society needs, the profession that can contribute to society is glorious. 2) Social practice is more important than book knowledge. It doesn't matter whether you go to school or not. 3) Teenagers should pursue high paying, comfortable and stable careers. 4) Choosing a career should avoid competition. Independent entrepreneurship is the best way to obtain employment.
answer: 4: As long as society needs, the profession that can contribute to society is glorious.

question: The hormone testosterone protects brain cells from injury and reduces levels of the protein beta-amyloid in the brain. Beta-amyloid causally contributes to Alzheimer' s disease, and people whose brain cells are susceptible to injury are probably more susceptible to Alzheimer' s disease. So there is reason to think that__. Which one of the following most logically completes the argument? 1) a decline in testosterone level puts one at increased risk for Alzheimer's disease 2) whether a person develops Alzheimer's disease is dependent entirely on the level of beta-amyloid in his or her brain 3) anyone whose brain cells are susceptible to injury will eventually develop Alzheimer's disease 4) only people with Alzheimer's disease are at risk for injury to brain cells
answer: 2: a decline in testosterone level puts one at increased risk for Alzheimer's disease

question: Global warming is considered an undisputed fact by most people, but data released by a climate change research institute shows that from the beginning of 1997 to August 2012, the overall temperature change of the world was only 0 degree. According to the agency, global warming has stopped. Which of the following, if true, should not doubt the institute's conclusion? 1) The timing of the start and end of climate trends is crucial, or they could skew the results.  2) The current computer models on which global temperature records are based are flawed, and the real climate is far more complex than they suggest.  3) For the study of global climate change, more than a decade's worth of data is only a short-term figure, not a telling data.  4) Global climate change is driven more by the movements of the earth itself than by human activity, according to new research.
answer: 3: Global climate change is driven more by the movements of the earth itself than by human activity, according to new research.

question: Patricia: During Japan' s Tokugawa period, martial arts experts known as ninjas were trained for the purposes of espionage and assassination. Yet at that time there was actually very little ninja activity in Japan, and most Japanese did not fear ninjas. Tamara: That is not true. Many wealthy Japanese during the Tokugawa period had their houses constructed with intentionally squeaky floors so that they would receive warning if a ninja were in the house. Of the following, which one, if true, is the strongest counter Patricia can make to Tamara's objection? 1) Many poor Japanese during the Tokugawa period also had houses constructed with intentionally squeaky floors. 2) As part of their secret training, ninjas learned to walk on squeaky floors without making a sound. 3) The wealthy made up a small portion of Japan's population during the Tokugawa period. 4) The fighting prowess of ninjas was exaggerated to mythic proportions in the years following the Tokugawa period.
answer: 4: The wealthy made up a small portion of Japan's population during the Tokugawa period.

question: A certain group company has six departments: production department, sales department, R & D department, personnel department, finance department and legal department. There are six office buildings from front to back: Wu ,Ji, Geng , Xin , Ren  and Gui . Each department has a building, and the arrangement of each department meets the following requirements: (1) the sales department is in front of the finance department and the production department. (2) the personnel department is immediately after the R & D department or the production department; (3) the legal department is followed by the R & D department or the sales department. If the sales department is located in the Wu building, which of the following arrangements is not possible? 1) The legal Department is in the Xin Building 2) The Personnel Department is in the Geng Building 3) The Finance Department is in the Gui Building 4) The R & D Department is in the Ji Building
answer: 2: The R & D Department is in the Ji Building

question: A, B, and C sell their products. Among the three products, one is counterfeit, and the other two are genuine. A said: My product is genuine, and B's product is counterfeit; B said: My product is genuine, and C's product is counterfeit; C said: B's product is genuine, A's product is counterfeit. It is known that one of A, B, and C told all turth, one half turth, half lie, and the other told all lies Well, who sells counterfeit goods? 1) A 2) Not sure 3) C 4) B

Artificial intelligence can imitate human intelligence and behavior, perceive the environment and make decisions and plans in a complex and changeable unknown environment, so as to actively perform tasks or complete set goals. According to the definition, which of the following belongs to the category of artificial intelligence? 1) After the user adds the clothes, the fully automatic washing machine can automatically complete a series of washing processes such as water filling, washing, water changing and drying 2) The assembly line robot can complete the assembly work of different parts of different machinery and equipment according to the parameters preset by the engineer 3) The personality test software can calculate according to the tester's various input parameters and according to the designed algorithm, so as to give the tester's personality description 4) The robot dog newly developed by Sony Corporation of Japan can identify men and women according to the characteristics of people's clothes and appearance, and greet different people with Hello, Mr. and Hello, Miss
answer: 4: The robot dog newly developed by Sony Corporation of Japan can identify men and women according to the characteristics of people's clothes and appearance, and greet different people with Hello, Mr. and Hello, Miss

question: Pediatrician: Swollen tonsils give rise to breathing problems during sleep, and the surgical removal of children' s swollen tonsils has been shown to alleviate sleep disturbances. So removing children' s tonsils before swelling even occurs will ensure that the children do not experience any breathing problems during sleep. The pediatrician's argument is most vulnerable to the criticism that it 1) fails to consider the possibility that some breathing problems during sleep may be caused by something other than swollen tonsils 2) fails to consider the possibility that there may be other medical reasons for surgically removing a child's tonsils 3) relies on an inappropriate appeal to authority 4) infers from the fact that an action has a certain effect that the action is intended to produce that effect
answer: 3: fails to consider the possibility that some breathing problems during sleep may be caused by something other than swollen tonsils

question: A survey has shown that some students lack creativity. Researchers believe that creative children are more naughty at an early age, and in some families, children will be severely reprimanded by their parents if they are naughty, which causes them to be obedient and less creative. Which of the following is the most supportive argument of this survey? 1) The way of education affects the development of children's creativity. 2) Childhood is a critical period for the development of creativity. 3) Some parents tend to take a harsher attitude towards children's mischief. 4) Young obedient children may lack creativity when they grow up.
answer: 4: Some parents tend to take a harsher attitude towards children's mischief.

question: Compared with genes, man-made components (artifacts) have a more powerful intervention in human evolution. From the controlled use of fire to the invention of stirrups and even supercomputers, from rough utensils to artistic creations, from primitive worship to nirvana? The recognition of the realm, from the gathering and hunting of food to the exploration of the fate of the universe. Cultural components change people's behavior and thinking, and even change the natural track of human genetic inheritance. Which of the following conforms to the context? 1) The influence of man-made components on human evolution 2) The natural track of human genes 3) The relationship between human genes and man-made components 4) The process of human evolution
answer: 3: The influence of man-made components on human evolution

question: Paleontologists had long supposed that the dinosaur Diplodocus browsed for high-growing vegetation such as treetop leaves by raising its very long neck. But now computer models have shown that the structure of Diplodocuss neck bones would have prevented such movement. The neck could, however, bend downward and even extend below ground level, allowing Diplodocus to access underwater vegetation from dry land. Thus, Diplodocus must have fed on plants on or near the ground, or underwater. Which one of the following is an assumption required by the argument? 1) Diplodocus was not able to browse for underwater vegetation by kneeling beside bodies of water or by walking into them. 2) Diplodocus had no other way of accessing high-growing vegetation, such as by rising up on its hind legs. 3) The same type of neck structure is found in modern ground-feeding animals. 4) Diplodocus was not able to see in front of itself unless its head was angled steeply downward.
answer: 4: Diplodocus had no other way of accessing high-growing vegetation, such as by rising up on its hind legs.

question: Parents who wish to provide a strong foundation for the musical ability of their children should provide them with a good musical education. Since formal instruction is often a part of a good musical education, parents who wish to provide this strong foundation need to ensure that their children receive formal instruction. The reasoning is most vulnerable to criticism on the grounds that it fails to consider that 1) some children might not be interested in receiving a strong foundation for their musical ability 2) parents might not be the only source of a child's musical education 3) formal instruction might not always be a part of a good musical education 4) there are many examples of people with formal instruction whose musical ability is poor
answer: 4: formal instruction might not always be a part of a good musical education

question: Since the reform and opening up, the structure of China's family has gradually changed from a large family of several generations to a nuclear family dominated by a family of three. In many cases, raising children and doing housework are difficult to solve through the division of labor within the family and need to seek help in the market. At the same time, with the improvement of people's living standards, the previous extensive child-rearing of adding a pair of chopsticks and a bowl is no longer feasible, and people's demand for high-level domestic service is becoming more and more normal. In particular, with the continuous emergence of new business models represented by Internet + and chain operation, the purchase of domestic service can be completed with the flick of a finger on the mobile phone, which brings a great opportunity for the development of the domestic service industry. Which of the following options is intended to describe this passage? 1) The change of Family structure in China affects the Management Model of domestic Service Industry 2) Internet promotes the rapid development of domestic service industry 3) Traditional domestic  service is difficult to meet the growing social demand. 4) The change of society promotes the development and growth of domestic service industry.
answer: 2: The change of society promotes the development and growth of domestic service industry.

question: Research from the University of Pavia in Italy shows that the brains of men and women who have just fallen in love send out instructions to make people secrete a chemical substance called love hormone, which makes people in love attract each other and produce a sense of security and satisfaction when hugging. Some scientists believe that love hormone is the cause of love Which of the followings best supports scientists' conclusions? 1) Paired voles also have a one night stand and even abandon their other half 2) Experts are working to treat abnormal diseases, such as stalkers 3) Injecting a hormone into the vole's brain will make the vole more attached to the other half 4) Oxytocin stimulation lasts only about a year
answer: 2: Injecting a hormone into the vole's brain will make the vole more attached to the other half

question: Value self-identifications means that people often overestimate the value of their actions and obtain happiness and beauty from it. Which of the following is value self-identifications? 1) Xiao Zhang just arrived at his workplace after graduation and was lucky enough to be assigned a bachelor apartment. It took him half a month to decorate the room like a new house. Every day he walked in, he was happy 2) Lao Zhao's work won the second prize of the Provincial Calligraphy Association. Colleagues came to congratulate him. He secretly made up his mind: He must strive to get a higher award next year 3) After Xiaoxing won the first prize in the campus robot competition, his father Lao Wu was happy all day, and he praised how good his son was when he met everyone 4) After Mr. Xie's famous song became popular overnight, he soon entered the film and television industry and appeared in many TV series. Although the audience response was mediocre, he has always been confident in his acting skills
answer: 3: After Mr. Xie's famous song became popular overnight, he soon entered the film and television industry and appeared in many TV series. Although the audience response was mediocre, he has always been confident in his acting skills

question: There are seven candidates hired by Haier: F, G, H, I, W, X and Y, of which one needs to be assigned to the public relations department, three to the production department and three to the sales department. The personnel allocation of these seven employees must meet the following conditions: (1) H and Y must be assigned to the same department. (2) F and G cannot be assigned to the same department. (3) if X is assigned to the sales department, W is assigned to the production department. (4) F must be assigned to the production department. If which of the following statements is true, the allocation of seven employees can be fully determined? 1) I and W are assigned to the sales department 2) I and W are assigned to the production department 3) G and Y are assigned to the sales department 4) F and W are assigned to the production department
answer: 3: I and W are assigned to the sales department

question: Although most rural couples in China have more than two children, almost all young people are moving to cities to work. Therefore, young and highly qualified immigrants will continue to hedge against the aging population in big cities, making the population relatively declining or flat, and the vitality of big cities will be maintained. In some places, the elderly are already supporting the countryside, and may even become the norm. Rural Japan is a cautionary tale. Which of the following does the text say? 1) Rural areas may age earlier than metropolises. 2) Population mobility will aggravate the imbalance between urban and rural development. 3) Population directly determines the development of a region. 4) China's aging population is as serious as Japan's.
answer: 2: Rural areas may age earlier than metropolises.

question: Many adults often remember only a few famous sentences in the three hundred Tang Poems that they were familiar with when they were children, but do not know the author or the name of the poem. There are only three grades of master's degree students in the Chinese Department of School A, and the number of students in each grade is equal. Statistics show that all the first-year students can match the famous sentences in the book with the poem names and their authors; the second-year students in 2 /3 can correspond to the famous sentences in the book with the author; and the students in grade 3 in 1/3 can't match the famous sentences in the book with the names of poems. According to the above information, which of the following can be obtained about the master's degree students in the Chinese department of the university? 1) The freshmen and sophomores above 1/ 3 can't match the famous sentences in the book with the author 2) Students with a master's degree above 1/3 cannot match the famous sentences in the book with the name of the poem or the author 3) Students in the first and third grades above 2/ 3  can match the famous sentences in the book with the names of the poems 4) Most master's degree students can match the famous sentences in the book with the name of the poem and its author
answer: 4: Students in the first and third grades above 2/ 3  can match the famous sentences in the book with the names of the poems

question: Using fossil energy more efficiently is in the interest of the nation and the global environment, but major improvements are unlikely unless proposed government standards are implemented to eliminate products or practices that are among the least efficient in their class. Objection: Decisions on energy use are best left to the operation of the market. Which one of the following, if true, most directly undermines the objection above? 1) Often the purchaser of a product, such as a landlord buying an appliance, chooses on the basis of purchase price because the purchaser is not the person who will pay for energy used by the product. 2) When energy prices rise, consumers of energy tend to look for new ways to increase energy efficiency, such as by adding insulation to their houses. 3) It would be unrealistic to expect society to make the changes necessary to achieve maximum energy efficiency all at once. 4) Whenever a new mode of generating energy, such as a new fuel, is introduced, a number of support systems, such as a fuel-distribution system, must be created or adapted.
answer: 1: Often the purchaser of a product, such as a landlord buying an appliance, chooses on the basis of purchase price because the purchaser is not the person who will pay for energy used by the product.

question: Sharing economy refers to realizing the socialization of production factors, improving the use efficiency of stock assets, creating more value and promoting the sustainable development of social economy based on the temporary transfer of the right to use idle resources with the help of the network third-party platform. According to the above definition, which of the following economic activities does not belong to the sharing economy? 1) Ma booked a home stay on an online platform before traveling and checked in after arriving. 2) Li made a loan to speculate in stocks on a network platform and obtained the expected income. 3) Wang booked a car to the airport on a network platform, which is convenient and fast. 4) Zhang bought takeout food on an online platform and enjoyed delicious food at home.
answer: 4: Zhang bought takeout food on an online platform and enjoyed delicious food at home.

question: The model in which the government cooperates with private enterprises to complete a certain project (referred to as PPP) can enable the government to obtain funds, and also allow social capital to enter the fields of public utilities such as electricity and railways. The problem in this model is that the government defaults or the investors default and cause economic losses to the other party. In previous PPP projects, government default was not a small probability event. Although local government defaults are not uncommon, investors are still actively investing in PPP projects. Which of the following statements, if true, best explains the above seemingly contradictory phenomenon? 1) The PPP model is relatively complicated, and the negotiating ability and PPP professional ability of local governments are not as good as that of investors 2) With the reform of the economic system and the promotion of new urbanization construction, the PPP model has high expectations from all walks of life 3) This year, the National Development and Reform Commission released 80 important projects to encourage social capital to participate in construction and operation through PPP and other means 4) In order to prevent the economic losses caused by the default of local governments, investors try to transfer other interests to their own enterprises
answer: 4: In order to prevent the economic losses caused by the default of local governments, investors try to transfer other interests to their own enterprises

question: Many leadership theories have provided evidence that leaders affect group success rather than the success of particular individuals. So it is irrelevant to analyze the effects of supervisor traits on the attitudes of individuals whom they supervise. Instead, assessment of leadership effectiveness should occur only at the group level. Which of the following would it be most useful to establish in order to evaluate the argument? 1) Whether some types of groups do not need supervision in order to be successful in their endeavors 2) Whether any of the leadership theories in question hold that leaders should assess other leaders' attitudes 3) Whether individuals' attitudes toward supervisors affect group success 4) Whether it is possible to assess individual supervisees' attitudes toward their supervisors without thereby changing those attitudes
answer: 2: Whether individuals' attitudes toward supervisors affect group success

question: On August 3, 2003, a 110000-year-old human tooth fossil about 3 cm in length was unearthed in Zhangkoudong Ancient Human site in Jiuxiang, Yiliang County.As soon as the excavation was announced, it immediately attracted wide attention from the media and experts. Many experts involved in the excavation believe that the appearance of this human tooth fossil shows that Zhangkoudong already had human activities as early as 110000 years ago, and it will rewrite the conclusion that human beings in Kunming area, as defined by the Longtan Mountain Ancient Human site in Chenggong County, have a history of only 30,000 years. Which of the followings, if true, can best question the views of the above experts? 1) Academia is inherently controversial, and everyone has the right to express their own opinions. 2) Some experts have analyzed the long axis of the tooth, the shape of the crown, the protrusion of the lip and tongue of the crown and the enamel of the fossil, and think that the fossil is not a fossil of human incisor, but a fossil of deer tooth. 3) The fossilized tooth was unearthed in a red sandy soil layer 20 cm below the calcium plate 110,000 years ago. 4) Some experts have used the uranium series method to determine the age of the calcium plates in each layer of Zhangkou Cave, proving that the earliest deposits in the cave where the tooth fossils were found were formed 300000 years ago.
answer: 2: Some experts have analyzed the long axis of the tooth, the shape of the crown, the protrusion of the lip and tongue of the crown and the enamel of the fossil, and think that the fossil is not a fossil of human incisor, but a fossil of deer tooth.

question: If he doesn't play the electric guitar, A jian Can't be the lead singer of the band. If he wants to play an instrument, he will choose to learn the electric guitar. If he doesn't play musical instruments, he will be the lead singer.If he doesn't play the electric guitar, Ken Can't be the lead singer of the band. If he wants to play an instrument, he will choose to learn the electric guitar. Which of the following options can be inferred? 1) To be the lead singer 2) Not to be the lead singer 3) Learning electric guitar 4) Not learning the electric guitar

Since ancient times, the study of rhetoric has always included the level of ethics. The so-called rhetoric is the skill, skill or art of using language to persuade others effectively. The ethical value of rhetoric as a public discourse includes good motivation, goodwill to others and the truth of the content of the discourse. If you leave or turn your back on such ethical values, speech skills will become a kind of improper rhetoric, a means that can be used to achieve an end, an improper sophistry or clever speech. Which of the following options is the central topic of this passage? 1) The rhetoric of public discourse. 2) The Ethical value of rhetoric. 3) The connotation of ethical value. 4) Object to sophistry or clever speech.

The annual Journal for Publication, which often solicits articles, publishes only those articles that are both submitted before March 6 and written by certified psychoanalysts. Stevens, who publishes frequently in psychoanalytic literature, submitted an article to the Journal before March 6. This article was accepted for publication in the Journal. Which one of the following conclusions follows logically from the statements above? 1) Stevens' recently accepted article will be interesting to Journal readers. 2) Stevens is an authority on a large number of topics in psychoanalysis. 3) Stevens is a psychoanalyst. 4) The Journal asked Stevens to write an article.

Experts believe that the disharmonious family atmosphere and lack of parental care are one of the reasons why teenagers have mental and spiritual problems, and then become addicted to online games. Family is a key place for children to experience emotions and develop emotional intelligence. If the family cannot provide children with the safety they need Feeling, respect, intimacy and love, children are likely to escape fear and loneliness and seek comfort in online games. Fathers who are busy with work and mothers who love to criticize and nag are often good at creating such an emotional ecology. If a person is full of adventurous spirits When the thrill-seeking boy leads a monotonous and unchanging life, the world of online games naturally looks wonderful. Which of the following is the main point of this passage? 1) Emotional absence easily makes children addicted to online games 2) Should create an emotional ecology that satisfies the children's personality 3) Harmonious parent-child relationship can make children stay out of online games 4) The emotional supply of children should be ensured as much as possible
answer: 2: Emotional absence easily makes children addicted to online games

question: Last Spring Festival, we sold 4 million yuan in welfare lotteries in only 2 days. In this Spring Festival, it is not a problem that we plan to sell 2,000 yuan in 10 days. Which of the followings best supports the above reasoning? 1) The sports lottery has always been favored by lottery buyers because the prizes are distributed in the form of bonuses. 2) The rapid development of sports in our country is inseparable from the support of the people across the country. We buy sports lotteries is also a kind of support for sports cause. 3) In the Spring Festival sports lottery sales event held the previous year, 10 million yuan of lotteries were sold in 5 days. 4) In the process of selling sports lotteries every year, we found that the daily sales volume is similar.
answer: 4: In the process of selling sports lotteries every year, we found that the daily sales volume is similar.

question: Student: The publications of Professor Vallejo on the origins of glassblowing have reopened the debate among historians over whether glassblowing originated in Egypt or elsewhere. If Professor Vallejo is correct, there is insufficient evidence for claiming, as most historians have done for many years, that glassblowing began in Egypt. So, despite the fact that the traditional view is still maintained by the majority of historians, if Professor Vallejo is correct, we must conclude that glassblowing originated elsewhere. Which one of the following is an error in the student's reasoning? 1) It confuses inadequate evidence for truth with evidence for falsity. 2) It mistakes the majority view for the traditional view. 3) It presupposes the truth of Professor Vallejo's claims. 4) It fails to provide criteria for determining adequate historical evidence.
answer: 3: It confuses inadequate evidence for truth with evidence for falsity.

question: The first human beings, in order to find enough food, often lived a wandering life, drifting to a place, that is, to find a temporary place to sleep. This frequent migration but comfortable way of living should be regarded as a transitional stage before human beings move from nesting to burrowing. Which of the following is the most accurate summary of the transitional stagein the text? 1) Human beings often lead a wandering life in order to find food 2) A form of residence that migrates frequently but is comfortable in the light of circumstances 3) Humans live wherever they find food 4) Wander somewhere, that is, find a makeshift place to spend the night
answer: 4: A form of residence that migrates frequently but is comfortable in the light of circumstances

question: Some people whose heart stops beating are actually declared dead by the law, but they can still be saved, while other people's body functions have completely disappeared, but due to the medical devices, the heart can still beating. In this case, he is actually dead man, still considered alive by law. Which of the following options is correct? 1) Using the stop of the heart as the basis for determining death may cause conflicts between the law and reality. 2) It is not possible to judge death or not by whether the heartbeat has stopped, otherwise it will embarrass the law enforcement officer. 3) It is difficult to change the concept that the heart is the ruler of the human body, and it is also difficult to change the law based on this. 4) With the development of modern science and technology, the law has been unable to make a clear judgment on whether the human body is disabled.
answer: 2: Using the stop of the heart as the basis for determining death may cause conflicts between the law and reality.

question: Winston: The Public Transportation Authority (PTA) cannot fulfill its mandate to operate without a budget deficit unless it eliminates service during late-night periods of low ridership. Since the fares collected during these periods are less than the cost of providing the service, these cuts would reduce the deficit and should be made. Transit law prohibits unauthorized fare increases, and fare-increase authorization would take two years. Ping: Such service cuts might cost the PTA more in lost fares than they would save in costs, for the PTA would lose those riders who leave home during the day but must return late at night. Thus the PTA would lose two fares, while realizing cost savings for only one leg of such trips. The relationship of Ping's response to Winston's argument is that Ping's response 1) introduces detailed statistical evidence that is more persuasive than that offered by Winston 2) supplies a premise that could have been used as part of the support for Winston's argument 3) questions Winston's proposal by raising considerations not addressed by Winston 4) carefully redefines a term used in Winston's argument
answer: 2: questions Winston's proposal by raising considerations not addressed by Winston

question: Glucocorticoid is a steroid hormone secreted by the adrenal cortex of the human body. It can regulate the synthesis and metabolism of sugars, fats and proteins. It is called glucocorticoid because its activity of regulating carbohydrate metabolism was first recognized by people. In addition, glucocorticoids can also regulate the inflammatory response, so they are often used as anti-inflammatory drugs to treat diseases caused by the overreaction of the immune system, such as allergies, asthma and rheumatoid arthritis. Glucocorticoids are also often used to fight inflammation in cancer patients. In cells, glucocorticoids need to interact with glucocorticoid receptors to exert their physiological functions. Which of the following options is the main content of this passage? 1) The function of glucocorticoid. 2) Characteristics of glucocorticoid. 3) The definition of glucocorticoid. 4) Properties of glucocorticoids.

Drinking two to 10 times a week is moderate. Men who drink two to ten times a week have a lower risk of heart disease than those who drink less than two times a week. Therefore, moderate drinking can reduce the risk of heart disease in men. Which of the following is true and least weakens the argument? 1) Men who drink moderately are more likely to be physically active 2) Men who drink moderately tend to be younger than those who drink less than twice a week 3) Women who drink moderately have a higher risk of hepatitis than women who drink less than twice a week 4) Men believe that if you are in good health, you can increase your drinking
answer: 1: Women who drink moderately have a higher risk of hepatitis than women who drink less than twice a week

question: A certain resident built illegally, which seriously affected the appearance of the city. Law enforcement officers said to him: If you do not demolish by yourself within the prescribed time limit, then we will demolish it in accordance with the law. The resident replied: I firmly disagree. According to the residents, which of the following judgments does he agree with? 1) Do not dismantle by yourself within the prescribed time limit, waiting for law enforcement officers to demolish according to law 2) Illegal construction seriously affects the appearance of the city, it is better to dismantle it 3) Demolition by itself within the specified time limit, without the need for law enforcement personnel to force demolition in accordance with the law 4) Resolutely not demolish within the prescribed time limit, and law enforcement personnel should not force demolishment according to law
answer: 2: Resolutely not demolish within the prescribed time limit, and law enforcement personnel should not force demolishment according to law

question: There are few perfect things in the world, even they don't exist. There are many things in the world, which are really perfect precisely because of their shortcomings. Incomplete and broken things sometimes magically produce a great power to shock our hearts. Therefore, we should open our mind and let our life go, appreciate the perfect gift brought to us by defects. Which of the following is inaccurate in understanding the above paragraph? 1) Rare things are precious. 2) As long as you try your best, you don't care whether the result is perfect or not. 3) Human joys and sorrows are inevitable. 4) No man is perfect.

Although the fact is that the sanitation inspection procedures of institutions that prepare banquets are much stricter than those of ordinary restaurants, there are more food poisoning cases reported to the municipal health department than ordinary restaurants. Which of the following can best explain the above phenomenon? 1) The organizations that prepare banquets know how many people they have to serve, so they are less likely to have surplus food than ordinary restaurants-a major cause of food poisoning 2) At any time, there are more people eating in restaurants than attending banquets 3) People are unlikely to establish a connection between eating a meal and the disease that ensues, unless the disease affects an interconnected group 4) The number of reported food poisoning cases at banquets has nothing to do with the nature of the service place
answer: 2: People are unlikely to establish a connection between eating a meal and the disease that ensues, unless the disease affects an interconnected group

question: As far as we know, Earth is the only planet on which life has evolved, and all known life forms are carbon-based. Ttherefore, although there might exist noncarbon-based life on planets very unlike Earth, our scientific estimates of the probability of extraterrestrial life should be generated from estimates of the number of planets like Earth and the likelihood of carbon-based life on those planets. Which one of the following general principles most strongly supports the recommendation? 1) It is preferable for scientists to restrict their studies to phenomena that are observable and forego making estimates about unobservable things. 2) A scientific theory that explains observed phenomena on the basis of a few principles that are independent of each other is preferable to a theory that explains those same phenomena on the basis of many independent principles. 3) Estimations of probability that are more closely tied to what is known are preferable to those that are less closely tied to what is known. 4) There is no good reason to think that unobserved phenomena closely resemble those that have been observed.
answer: 1: Estimations of probability that are more closely tied to what is known are preferable to those that are less closely tied to what is known.

question: Commentator: For a free market to function properly, each prospective buyer of an item must be able to contact a large number of independent prospective sellers and compare the prices charged for the item to what the item is worth. Thus, despite advertised prices and written estimates available from many of its individual businesses, the auto repair industry does not constitute a properly functioning free market. The conclusion of the commentator's argument follows logically if which one of the following is assumed? 1) Because it is not regulated, the auto repair industry does not have standardized prices. 2) Many auto repair shops charge more for auto repairs than these repairs are worth. 3) Some persons who are shopping for auto repairs cannot determine what these repairs are worth. 4) People do not usually shop for auto repairs but instead take their autos to their regular repair shop out of habit.
answer: 4: Some persons who are shopping for auto repairs cannot determine what these repairs are worth.

question: The early universe contained only the lightest elements: hydrogen and helium. Heavier elements such as carbon can only be formed in the nuclear reaction of a star and spread when the star explodes. A recently discovered nebula contains carbon formed billions of years ago, when the universe was no more than 1.5 billion years old. If the above statement is true, which of the followings must be true? 1) The carbon in this nebula later formed part of some stars 2) The earliest stars contained only hydrogen 3) When the universe was less than 1.5 billion years old, some stars had already formed 4) This nebula also contains hydrogen and helium
answer: 2: When the universe was less than 1.5 billion years old, some stars had already formed

question: Scientists conjecture that certain microbes consume organic molecules in exposed shale and similar sediments. In so doing, the microbes remove oxygen from the atmosphere and generate carbon dioxide, a gas that, evidence indicates, promotes global warming. They also conjecture that these microbes reproduce more quickly at higher temperatures. The scientists' conjectures, if true, provide the most support for which one of the following statements? 1) If global warming occurs, it will be exacerbated by the activity of the microbes. 2) Every organism that generates carbon dioxide reproduces more quickly at high temperatures. 3) The microbes' activity will soon diminish as the organic molecules in exposed sediments are depleted. 4) The microbes do not remove any element other than oxygen from the atmosphere.
answer: 3: If global warming occurs, it will be exacerbated by the activity of the microbes.

question: It is generally believed that waste old TV picture tubes (cathode ray tube) is a waste containing toxic substances. But a new study shows that this waste may be useful. Researchers placed chips of cathode ray tube glass between a cobalt radiation source with a radioactivity of 800 trillion Becquerels and an instrument for measuring radiation dose to determine its ability to shield radiation. The analysis results show that even if the chips of cathode ray tube glass are not tested Any processing, 55 cm thick glass debris can reduce the radiation dose to the original 1%, which is equivalent to the shielding capacity of about 9 cm thick lead plate, and lead is considered to be the material with the strongest ability to absorb and shield nuclear radiation. If the glass debris is mixed with the glass powder produced by crushing cathode ray tubes, the above effect can be achieved by about 40 cm thick. With regard to the glass debris of cathode ray tube, which of the following statements is correct: 1) The fineness of its processing will affect its ability to shield nuclear radiation 2) The view that it contains toxic substances has been questioned 3) The ability to absorb nuclear radiation is comparable to that of lead 4) With the increase of thickness, its ability to shield nuclear radiation will also be improved
answer: 4: The fineness of its processing will affect its ability to shield nuclear radiation

question: At a comprehensive academic annual meeting, the people who give academic presentations by the Physics Society are from colleges and universities; the people who give academic presentations by the Chemical Society are from colleges and universities, but most of them are from middle schools; and other academic presentations are from the Academy of Sciences. All the academic reporters from colleges and universities have the titles of associate professor or above, and those from middle schools have the professional titles of senior secondary education or above. Li Mo and Zhang Hao attended this comprehensive academic annual meeting. Li Mo is not from middle school, and Zhang Hao is not from a university. If the above statement is true, which of the following conclusions can be drawn? 1) If Li Mo has made an academic report, then he is not a member of the Chemical Society 2) Zhang Mo does not have the title of associate professor or above 3) Li Mo is not a member of the Chemical Society 4) If Zhang Hao made an academic report, then he would not be a member of the Physics Society
answer: 1: If Zhang Hao made an academic report, then he would not be a member of the Physics Society

question: The four offices of a certain agency, A, B, C, and D, are preparing for in-depth investigations at the grassroots level. The places they are preparing to investigate are Hongxing Township, Chaoyang Township, Yongfeng Street, and Xingfu Street. Each room chooses exactly one place and it is different. Known: (1) Either A chooses Xingfu Street, or B chooses Xingfu Street, and the two must be one of them;(2) either A chooses Red Star Township or C chooses Yongfeng County Street; (3) if C chooses Yongfeng County Street, D chooses Happy Street. Based on the above statement, which of the following can be concluded? 1) B choose Hongxing Township. 2) A choose Chaoyang Township. 3) C choose Xingfu Street. 4) D chose Yongfeng Street.

While traveling in Russia, the French writer Dumas came to a city and decided to visit the largest bookstore in the city. When the owner heard that the writer was coming, he put duma's books on all the shelves, to duma's delight. Duma went into the bookstore and looked. 'The boss said,' All...... Sold out. What this joke is about? 1) The boss is flustered and unprepared. 2) No one buys dumas' books. 3) The boss's answer was contrary to his wishes. 4) The boss satirized Dumas for not selling his book.
answer: 3: The boss's answer was contrary to his wishes.

question: Dumping is defined as the act of selling a commodity in another country at a price below the cost of its production. Shrimp producers in country H are selling river prawns in country M at a price lower than the cost of producing the prawns in country M. So the shrimp producers in country H are dumping shrimp in country M. Which of the followings is necessary to assess the dumping practices mentioned above? 1) If country H keeps selling shrimp in country M at a price lower than country M's shrimp production cost, country M's shrimp industry will go bankrupt 2) The cost of production in the definition of dumping refers to the cost of production in the place of origin of the product, or the cost of production of the same kind of product in the place of sale 3) Due to different methods of calculating the production cost of a commodity, it is difficult to come up with an accurate comparative value of the production cost of the same commodity in different countries 4) Experts agree on whether dumping is harmful or beneficial to the economies of both countries, or just one of them
answer: 1: The cost of production in the definition of dumping refers to the cost of production in the place of origin of the product, or the cost of production of the same kind of product in the place of sale

question: Crisis sinking refers to the excessive worry of young people when faced with problems that should not occur until the next age group. Which of the following options belongs to the crisis sinking? 1) Xiao Huang graduated four or five years ago and is still single. She is worried that it will be difficult for her to find a suitable partner if she puts it off any longer 2) Xiao Li has just been admitted to Jiangcheng University. Seeing the skyrocketing housing prices around him, Xiao Li is worried that he cannot afford to buy a house after graduation and cannot settle down 3) Whenever I think of the retirement life that will begin in two years' time, Lao Zhang feels inexplicably lost and anxious 4) Recently, Mr. and Mrs. Xiao Liang are so worried about their daughter's going to primary school next year that they can't afford to buy a school district house in the famous school they like
answer: 2: Xiao Li has just been admitted to Jiangcheng University. Seeing the skyrocketing housing prices around him, Xiao Li is worried that he cannot afford to buy a house after graduation and cannot settle down

question: If the wastewater discharged from the production of a certain brand of chemical fertilizer enters the river, it will lead to the non-spawning of red trout, resulting in the reduction of the number of fish. After a chemical plant built not far from the river produced the brand of chemical fertilizer, the number of red trout spawned by farmers in the basin decreased sharply. Therefore, the chemical plant must have polluted the river when producing chemical fertilizer. Which of the following contains the most similar reasoning errors to the above reasoning? 1) Malnourished people are easy to get sick. Li is very fat, but there is no malnutrition in all indicators, so he is certainly not easy to get sick. 2) Double cooked pork slices can be eaten by fat eating meat. Incidence rate of cardiovascular disease is increasing. Recently, Lao Wang went out for dinner and had two times of cooking pork twice. 3) People with severe insomnia often stay up late. Zhang is a university teacher and often stays up late until two o'clock, so Zhang is likely to be a person with severe insomnia. 4) People who are positive for Helicobacter pylori will get gastric ulcer. Zhang has gastric ulcer disease, so Zhang's Helicobacter pylori must be positive.
answer: 3: People who are positive for Helicobacter pylori will get gastric ulcer. Zhang has gastric ulcer disease, so Zhang's Helicobacter pylori must be positive.

question: Blockchain is an accounting system for distributed storage of information. its most important feature is that it can establish a trust relationship without relying on the trust endorsement of the central platform in a network environment without trust basis. its practical application starts with Bitcoin as a virtual currency. However, the application of blockchain technology is not limited to virtual currency. At present, blockchain technology has been applied to a certain extent in the fields of financial supervision, data sharing, car networking, Internet finance, banking, insurance, supply chain finance, clearing and settlement center and so on. If the blockchain is only equated with virtual currency and hyped at this time, it is either biased or deliberately distorted for the sake of hype.
