Which of the following is the content that this text is meant to emphasize? 1) The potential value of blockchain technology needs to be further explored 2) Block chain contributes to the establishment of social credit management system 3) Blockchain technology has been widely used in the market 4) It is wrong to equate blockchain technology with virtual currency
answer: 3: It is wrong to equate blockchain technology with virtual currency

question: Studies have shown that highway drivers are less likely to drive at speeds greater than the posted speed limit if houses or buildings are in some way visible from the road. Assuming similar car, road and traffic conditions, highway drivers are more likely to drive at speeds in excess of the posted speed limit if the natural surroundings are not interrupted by buildings. Psychologists hypothesize that seeing signs of civilization reminds drivers of their responsibility to the safety of their fellow humans, thus making them more likely to obey the posted speed limit. Which of the following, if true, most strongly supports the psychologists' interpretation of the study? 1) Highway police officers are more densely located close to towns and cities, and ttherefore most citations for speeding are issued in these locations. 2) Drivers are equally likely to obey the speed limit whether driving past a town with or without tall buildings. 3) Traffic tends to be more congested around towns and cities. 4) Highway drivers passing a large plowed and cultivated field are more likely to obey the speed limit than those passing a large field of wild flowers.
answer: 1: Highway drivers passing a large plowed and cultivated field are more likely to obey the speed limit than those passing a large field of wild flowers.

question: Students who want to work as lawyers apply for law major. Mao Ning has applied for law major, so he must want to work as a lawyer. Which of the followings, if true, supports the above view most?? 1) All candidates for the law major want to work as lawyers 2) Many lawyers have legal degrees 3) Some lawyers are university law graduates 4) Some people who want to work as lawyers have applied for law majors
answer: 1: All candidates for the law major want to work as lawyers

question: A blogger declared: my analysis of the future trend of housing prices has been followed by more than 1000 netizens, I counted, 85% of the posts agree with me.This shows that most people agree with me.  Which of the following most questions the blogger's conclusion? 1) Some posts with dissenting views have more reason 2) Although some people agree with his point of view, they do not agree with his analysis 3) Most of the people who follow the blogger's article are loyal fans 4) The blogger's other articles with high approval ratings later proved to be wrong
answer: 4: Most of the people who follow the blogger's article are loyal fans

question: Close association in psychology refers to things that are close in time and space tend to form associations in people's experience. According to the above definition, which of the following is close to association? 1) When you see a cat, you think tiger. 2) When you recall the pain of being oppressed and exploited in the old society, you will realize that a happy life in the new society has not come easily. 3) When you see Lightning, you think of thunder. 4) When you see a child, you think of your mother.
answer: 4: When you see Lightning, you think of thunder.

question: German psychologist Ringelmann has a famous tug-of-war experiment: When the number of people in the tug-of-war gradually increases, each person uses less power, which does not achieve the effect of power accumulation. This phenomenon is called ringelmann effect, also called social escape. According to the above definition, which of the followings does not belong to the ringelmann effect ? 1) Many chickens do not lay eggs, and too many people are prone to chaos. 2) Divide the male college students into groups of 2, 4, and 6 each. Ask them to shout loudly and record the volume of each person. It turns out that the individual's volume decreases as the number of groups increases. 3) Many people think that the fortune teller is very accurate after consulting a fortune teller. 4) A group of people watched someone in need, but few people really offered a helping hand.
answer: 3: Many chickens do not lay eggs, and too many people are prone to chaos.

question: If Xiao Zhang goes to Xinjiang this summer, he must visit Turpan and Kanas, otherwise he will not go; only if he travels with Xiao Li will Xiao Zhang visit Turpan or Tianchi; if he travels with Xiao Li, Xiao Zhang must make an agreement with Xiao Li; if Xiao Zhang makes an agreement with Xiao Li, Xiao Li must have time this summer. Unfortunately, this summer, Xiao Li unit came to an urgent task, related personnel are not allowed to ask for leave, Xiao Li is no exception. Based on this, it can be concluded that which of the followings is correct? 1) Xiao Zhang is going to visit Tianchi this summer 2) Xiao Zhang is going to visit Kanas this summer 3) Xiao Zhang didn't go to Xinjiang this summer 4) Xiao Zhang is going to visit Turpan this summer
answer: 1: Xiao Zhang didn't go to Xinjiang this summer

question: The incidence of cancer is related to genes. If the gene mutates and becomes too active, it will drive the occurrence of cancer. Similarly, if the tumor suppressor gene mutates and loses its function, it will also promote cancer. PTEN is a tumor suppressor gene prone to mutation. It has been found that an E3 ubiquitin ligase called WWP1 binds to PTEN, affecting its anti-cancer function. Inhibiting the function of WWP1 can liberate PTEN, restore the inhibition of PTEN on cancer, and thus play an anti-cancer role. Studies have confirmed that a natural compound called indole-3-methanol (I3C) can effectively inhibit the function of WWP1, which is very common in cruciferous plants such as broccoli. According to the above discussion, which of the following options is correct? 1) Eating cruciferous vegetables such as broccoli helps to treat cancer. 2) The higher the content of WWP1, the lower the content of PTEN. 3) E3 ubiquitin ligase affects the occurrence of cancer by acting on oncogenes. 4) I3C helps to restore the anti-cancer function of PTEN.
answer: 4: I3C helps to restore the anti-cancer function of PTEN.

question: Editorial: The threat of harsh punishment for a transgression usually decreases one' s tendency to feel guilt or shame for committing that transgression, and the tendency to feel guilt or shame for committing a transgression reduces a person' s tendency to commit transgressions. Thus, increasing the severity of the legal penalties for transgressions may amplify people' s tendency to ignore the welfare of others. Which one of the following is an assumption required by the editorial's argument? 1) At least some actions that involve ignoring the welfare of others are transgressions. 2) People who are concerned about threats to their own well-being tend to be less concerned about the welfare of others. 3) Everyone has at least some tendency to feel guilt or shame for committing extremely severe transgressions. 4) The threat of harsh punishment deters people from committing transgressions only if this threat is at least sometimes carried out.
answer: 4: At least some actions that involve ignoring the welfare of others are transgressions.

question: The average life expectancy of the population is an important indicator reflecting the health level of the people in a country and region. The sixth national census shows that the average life expectancy of the Chinese population reached 74.83 years in 2010, while the average life expectancy of the population in the early days of the founding of the People's Republic of China was only about 35 years. Therefore, the elderly people that people thought more than sixty years ago now seem to be just middle-aged people. Which of the followings, if true, would most weaken the above point of view? 1) In the early days of the founding of the People's Republic of China, the living environment was more difficult, and people's nutritional level was much worse than it is now. 2) In the early days of the founding of the People's Republic of China, the country was shifting from war to peace. The situation in the country was still unstable and the population was much lower than it is now. 3) With the development of medicine, the level of medical care has been greatly improved compared with the early days of the founding of the People's Republic of China. 4) Since the founding of the People's Republic of China, the decrease in the number of newborn infant deaths is the most important reason for the increase in the average life expectancy of the population.
answer: 1: Since the founding of the People's Republic of China, the decrease in the number of newborn infant deaths is the most important reason for the increase in the average life expectancy of the population.

question: The crime of fraud refers to the act of defrauding a large amount of public and private property by making up facts or concealing the truth for the purpose of illegal possession. According to the above definition, which of the following can constitute the crime of fraud? 1) A sales lady sold the real estate at the subway entrance to customer B, saying that there was a lot of room for appreciation. Two months after B bought the house, house prices fell sharply, causing B to suffer heavy losses. 2) When A sold his villa at a low price, he hid the fact that there had been a murder, causing B to buy it without knowing it. 3) The person in charge of a gas station makes the actual amount of fuel less than the number displayed by the machine by moving his hands and feet on the meter, so as to obtain a large amount of income. 4) A pretends to buy a suit in the mall, and salesperson B asks him to try it on. After wearing the suit, A claims to look in the mirror and sneak away while B receives other customers.
answer: 2: The person in charge of a gas station makes the actual amount of fuel less than the number displayed by the machine by moving his hands and feet on the meter, so as to obtain a large amount of income.

question: Framing effect refers to the fact that the same information, expressed in different ways, will lead to different decision-making. In general, in terms of losses and gains, people tend to focus on losses. Based on the above definition, which of the following is the least likely to have the framing effect? 1) When see a financial product can 100% probability to make their own profit 10% and B product can make their own 85% probability of profit 200% , Xiao Hong resolutely chose to invest in B product. 2) The probability of a car accident at the bus terminal A is only 0.001%, while the probability of a car accident at the bus terminal  B is 99.999%. Seeing this, the passenger Xiao Kun chose to take the bus at the bus terminal B. 3) Xiao Ming can get one loaf every day. When asked Have you eaten half a loaf, do you still eat it?, he chooses not to eat it; and if you ask There is half a loaf, do you eat it?, he chose to eat it all. 4) Sales at a Milk Company have soared after the company changed its description of its milk products from 3% fatto 97% fat-freebecause of consumer resistance to fat.
answer: 2: When see a financial product can 100% probability to make their own profit 10% and B product can make their own 85% probability of profit 200% , Xiao Hong resolutely chose to invest in B product.

question: Expanding and narrowing topics are very common in debate competitions. In mutual argument, debaters often deliberately expand each other's topics and push each other's topics to the point of absurdity, so as to facilitate their own refutation and attack; At the same time, in order to facilitate their argument and defense, debaters often deliberately narrow their argument. According to the above definition, which of the followings uses the expanded topic? 1) The thesis human nature is evil is interpreted as man has innate instinct and desire, so human nature is evil 2) The thesis the disadvantages of heterosexual communication among middle school students outweigh the advantages is interpreted as the disadvantages of too close heterosexual communication among middle school students must outweigh the advantages 3) The thesis human nature is good is interpreted as no one is not good 4) Interpret the topic Germans are very rigorous as all Germans are very rigorous
answer: 3: Interpret the topic Germans are very rigorous as all Germans are very rigorous

question: People in isolated rain-forest communities tend to live on a largely vegetarian diet, and they eat little salt. Few of them suffer from high blood pressure, and their blood pressure does not tend to increase with age, as is common in industrialized countries. Such people often do develop high blood pressure when they move to cities and adopt high-salt diets. Though suggestive, these facts do not establish salt as the culprit in high blood pressure, however, because__. Which of the following most logically completes the argument given below? 1) genetic factors could account for the lack of increase of blood pressure with age among such people 2) there are changes in other aspects of diet when such people move to the city 3) salt is a necessity for human life, and death can occur when the body loses too much salt 4) it is possible to have a low-salt diet while living in a city in an industrialized country
answer: 3: there are changes in other aspects of diet when such people move to the city

question: According to medical theory, a person must exercise enough if he wants to be healthy, but people in the city often use cars and other means of transportation and do not have enough exercise. Therefore, this medical theory is not valid. Which of the followings is the most likely presupposition of the above argument? 1) Transportation is necessary for people in city 2) People in city can't be unhealthy 3) People in city lived a fast-paced life 4) Some people in city pay attention to exercise for health
answer: 4: People in city can't be unhealthy

question: Four teenagers A, B, C and D have three kinds of electronic products: mobile phone, computer and camera.  Two, three people have a cell phone, two have a computer, and only one has a camera.  Three, each person owns at least one of the three electronic products;  Four,Whether A and B have a computer is the same (either both or neither of them have a computer);  Five, Whether B and C have mobile phones is the same;  Sixth, C and D are different in whether they have mobile phones. Combined with the above conclusion, which of the following options is the person who owns the camera? 1) C 2) D 3) B 4) A

Life is often like this: if you don't let others live, you will eventually kill yourself; if you give others a chance, you will give yourself a chance. Which of the following is not understood correctly? 1) In life, people need to understand and tolerate each other 2) You have to kill your opponent in order to survive 3) Helping others is actually helping yourself 4) Mankind needs interdependence and common development
answer: 3: You have to kill your opponent in order to survive

question: Thinking: refers to the human brain's reflection of objective and indirect generalizations. Thinking can be divided into (1) action thinking, which refers to the thinking supported by actual actions in the thinking process according to the object or the state of thinking in the thinking process. Its characteristic is that the task is intuitive, given in a concrete form, and the solution is actual action; (2) Thinking in images refers to the process of analyzing, synthesizing, abstracting, and summarizing appearances. It is characterized by vivid , vivid and objective Image; (3) Abstract thinking refers to the process of using concepts, judgments, reasoning and other forms to reflect the law of movement of objective things, and to recognize the essential characteristics and internal connections of things. Which of the following options meets the definition of action thinking? 1) Holmes, by finding no other exit in the house, concluded that the murderer must have exited the chimney on the roof, even though the chimney was small 2) From an early age, Hong's son was required to watch his father practice kung fu every day.Gradually, he could follow his father's lead 3) When designing architectural plans, students in the Department of Architecture sometimes need to make a model based on the architectural drawings first, which seems to be more helpful to discover the flaws in the architectural design 4) Professor Liu likes to illustrate the problem by enumerating a large number of examples in his articles
answer: 2: From an early age, Hong's son was required to watch his father practice kung fu every day.Gradually, he could follow his father's lead

question: A working group plans to conduct field research and initially determine that only one region in eastern, western or northern Guangdong will be selected. In this regard, three people in the working group A, B, C put forward the following opinions: A: eastern Guangdong is more representative in this survey and should go to eastern Guangdong. B: I have already been to northern Guangdong in the last round of research, so we should choose other regions this time. C: I think it is more appropriate to choose western or northern Guangdong to conduct field research. In the end, the working group adopted only one person's opinion. Which of the following options must be correct? 1) The working group adopted opinion of B. 2) The working group went to the western Guangdong. 3) The working group adopted opinion of C. 4) The working group went to eastern Guangdong.
answer: 4: The working group adopted opinion of C.

question: Pieces of music consist of sounds and silences presented to the listener in a temporal order. A painting, in contrast, is not presented one part at a time to the viewer; there is thus no particular path that the viewer' s eye must follow in order to read the painting. Ttherefore, an essential distinction between the experiences of hearing music and of viewing paintings is that hearing music has a temporal dimension but viewing a painting has none. The reasoning in the argument is flawed because 1) relying on the metaphor of reading to characterize how a painting is viewed presupposes the correctness of the conclusion to be drawn on the basis of that characterization 2) the argument does not allow for the possibility of being immersed in experiencing a painting without being conscious of the passage of time 3) the absence of a particular path that the eye must follow does not entail that the eye follows no path 4) the argument fails to bring out the aspects of music and painting that are common to both as forms of artistic expression
answer: 3: the absence of a particular path that the eye must follow does not entail that the eye follows no path

question: Scientists in Denmark and Japan have found that whether young parents smoke is related to the ratio of babys' gender. If both parents do not smoke, the ratio of boys to girls is 1.214 to 1. If both parents smoke more than 20 cigarettes a day, the ratio of  boys to girls drops to 0.823 to 1. Even if only one person smokes and is not addicted to cigarettes, the probability of having a boy will decrease. The reason may be that the sperm or male embryos carrying the Y chromosome are more likely to be harmed by smoking. Except for smoking , emotional stress and environmental pollution factors can also cause a decline in the proportion of male babies. Which of the following options can be inferred? 1) Male's Y chromosome is more fragile than X chromosome. 2) Smoking parents have a lower chance than no-smoking parents to have a boy. 3) X chromosome will not be affected by smoking, so the chance of giving birth to a girl is greater. 4) There are more men than women in the world because non-smokers make up the majority.
answer: 3: Smoking parents have a lower chance than no-smoking parents to have a boy.

question: In some places, we often see beautiful aurora at night. This strange and mysterious aurora has always attracted us. The reason for the aurora is that high-energy particles (electrons and protons) from outside the atmosphere hit atoms in the upper atmosphere. It is now known that, as part of the solar wind, charged particles are captured by the earth's magnetic field when they arrive near the earth, and they collide with oxygen and nitrogen atoms, Strike away electrons and make them excited ions. These ions emit radiation of different wavelengths and produce aurora in red, green or blue. The formation of aurora is closely related to solar activity. Every year when solar activity is active, you can see a more spectacular Aurora scene. When the night comes, red, blue and green lights fill the night sky, which is extremely spectacular. The most suitable title for this paragraph is: 1) The formation of aurora is related to solar activity 2) How did the aurora form 3) The aurora can't be seen at most areas 4) The aurora scene is extremely spectacular

Politician: All nations that place a high tax on income produce thereby a negative incentive for technological innovation, and all nations in which technological innovation is hampered inevitably fall behind in the international arms race. Those nations that, through historical accident or the foolishness of their political leadership, wind up in a strategically disadvantageous position are destined to lose their voice in world affairs. So if a nation wants to maintain its value system and way of life, it must not allow its highest tax bracket to exceed 30 percent of income. Each of the following, if true, weakens the politician's argument EXCEPT: 1) Falling behind in the international arms race does not necessarily lead to a strategically less advantageous position. 2) Allowing one's country to lose its technological edge, especially as concerns weaponry, would be foolish rather than merely a historical accident. 3) The top level of taxation must reach 45 percent before taxation begins to deter inventors and industrialist from introducing new technologies and industries. 4) Those nations that lose influence in the world community do not necessarily suffer from a threat to their value system or way of life.
answer: 2: Allowing one's country to lose its technological edge, especially as concerns weaponry, would be foolish rather than merely a historical accident.

question: Asymmetric information refers to information that some actors possess that others do not. Which of the following options is asymmetrical information, as defined above? 1) A TV shopping channel joined forces with building materials merchants to carry out group purchase promotion, Xiao Li said he did not know 2) An enterprise publishes information, hires a department manager, requires men, age not more than 30 years old, after passing the examination interview.  Candidate A, B all the way through, into the final round of screening, in deciding who won the final, B was told, because it is not the city account, so not to be hired 3) A city in the city's major media released the recruitment of 50 civil servants news, Zhang said he has been in the field recently, do not know the news, so missed the registration time 4) A unit held a general meeting on the first day of work after the Spring Festival, which stipulated that workers should not play games during working hours.  A month later, Xiao Li violation was dealt with, Xiao Li argued that the unit had previously requested, and later did not make a similar request
answer: 1: An enterprise publishes information, hires a department manager, requires men, age not more than 30 years old, after passing the examination interview.  Candidate A, B all the way through, into the final round of screening, in deciding who won the final, B was told, because it is not the city account, so not to be hired

question: The combat effectiveness of an army depends on the armamentthe and quality of the personnel.Georgia, which suffered heavy losses in the 2008 conflict with Russian troops, is prepared to spend 9 billion dollars to rearm its troops with modern equipment. Although the United States strongly supports Georgia in strengthening its military forces, it is not prepared to sell advanced weapons to it. Which of the following options does not explain this practice in the United States? 1) Georgian warplanes gave up taking off a few hours after the start of the war, and the patrol boats were directly captured by Russian troops and carried away by trucks. 2) The Georgian army, which has been preparing for the war for three years, is vulnerable despite being fully equipped with American equipment. 3) A senior general of the Georgian army fled and abandoned his troops. 4) Russia is ready to ask the Security Council to impose an arms embargo on Georgia.
answer: 1: Russia is ready to ask the Security Council to impose an arms embargo on Georgia.

question: Insufficient rain can cause crops to falter and agricultural prices to rise. Records indicate that during a certain nation' s recent crisis, faltering crops and rising agricultural prices prompted the government to take over food distribution in an effort to prevent starvation. Thus, the weather must have played an important role in bringing about the crisis. The argument's reasoning is most vulnerable to criticism on the grounds that the argument 1) infers, merely from the fact that one event could have caused a second event, that the first event in fact caused the second 2) fails to take into account the possibility that the scarcity was not severe enough to justify the government's taking over food distribution 3) concludes, merely from the fact that the period of insufficient rain occurred before the nation's crisis, that insufficient rain caused the nation's crisis 4) uses the term crisis equivocally in the reasoning, referring to both a political crisis and an economic crisis
answer: 1: infers, merely from the fact that one event could have caused a second event, that the first event in fact caused the second

question: Zhang Hua said to Wang Lei: you tell me that as the legal owner of the company, I have the right to sell it as long as I want to. However, you told me that if I sold it, loyal employees would suffer as a result, so I had no right to do so. Obviously, your two statements are contradictory. Which of the following options most accurately describes the defect in Zhang Hua's inference? 1) Zhang Hua has no right to sell his company now, which does not mean that he will never have the right to sell it. 2) Zhang Hua ignored that his employees also have the right to sell the company. 3) Zhang Hua confused the ownership of the company with the right to be responsible for loyal employees. 4) Zhang Hua did not provide a sufficient and reliable reason to sell his company.
answer: 4: Zhang Hua confused the ownership of the company with the right to be responsible for loyal employees.

question: Oscar: Emerging information technologies will soon make speed of information processing the single most important factor in the creation of individual, corporate, and national wealth. Consequently, the division of the world into northern countries -- in general rich -- and southern countries -- in general poor -- will soon be obsolete. Instead, there simply will be fast countries and slow countries, and thus a country' s economic well-being will not be a function of its geographical position but just a matter of its relative success in incorporating those new technologies. Sylvia: But the poor countries of the south lack the economic resources to acquire those technologies and will ttherefore remain poor. The technologies will thus only widen the existing economic gap between north and south. Sylvia's reasoning depends on the assumption that 1) the speed at which information processing takes place will continue to increase indefinitely 2) at least some of the rich countries of the north will be effective in incorporating new information technologies into their economies 3) there are technologies other than information technologies whose development could help narrow the existing economic gap between north and south 4) the prosperity of the rich countries of the north depends, at least in part, on the natural resources of the poor countries of the south
answer: 3: at least some of the rich countries of the north will be effective in incorporating new information technologies into their economies

question: The sequelae of digital technology refers to the phenomenon of memory decline or cognitive decline caused by overuse and dependence on digital products. Which of the following is the sequelae of digital technology? 1) Xiao Li and a few friends went to the Internet cafe to play all night together on the weekend. When he walked out of the Internet cafe the next morning, hefelt that the pedestrians on the side of the road were vague 2) Xiao Zhu's sense of direction is very good. He used to drive without a navigator. Since installing the navigator, he can't do without it for a day. The navigator broke down last night, and he drove it for two hours in the original 15-minute drive 3) Ms. Zhang has repeatedly heard from friends that you can buy wealth management products directly on your mobile phone, so she downloaded a wealth management app. Unexpectedly, she went to a phishing website and was deceived by more than 30,000 yuan 4) Mr. Ding, who is in his sixties, has a worsening memory, and many documents that were once overwhelmingly familiar are now not remembered clearly, and he often needs to use his mobile phone to search and verify the relevant content
answer: 1: Xiao Zhu's sense of direction is very good. He used to drive without a navigator. Since installing the navigator, he can't do without it for a day. The navigator broke down last night, and he drove it for two hours in the original 15-minute drive

question: Now most plastic cans that can be discarded after use are affixed with a number (from 1 to 9) that indicates the type or quality of the plastic. The plastic with the lowest number is the easiest to be recycled by the recycling factory, and the one with the highest number are rarely recycled. Therefore, consumers can refuse to buy products that are packaged in the highest-numbered affixed plastic products to significantly reduce the long-term non-recyclable waste. Which of the followings, if correct, could weaken the above conclusion most? 1) Those communities that collect all discarded plastic containers for future recycling will dump the higher-numbered plastic into the garbage only when there is obviously no recycler to recycle them. 2) At present, the cost of collecting, sorting and recycling discarded plastic waste is higher than that of new plastic products made from raw materials. 3) Many consumers did not notice the number printed on the plastic containers. 4) After the plastic container is recycled, the number almost always rises, because the recycling process will reduce the quality of the plastic products.
answer: 2: Many consumers did not notice the number printed on the plastic containers.

question: The size of northern fur seals provides a reliable indication of their population levels -- the smaller the average body size of seals in a population, the larger the population. Archaeologists studied seal fossils covering an 800-year period when the seals were hunted for food by Native peoples in North America and found that the average body size of the seals did not vary significantly. The statements above, if true, provide the most support for which one of the following? 1) Before the 800-year period studied, the average body size of northern fur seals fluctuated dramatically. 2) During the 800-year period studied, seal hunting practices did not vary substantially between different groups of Native peoples in North America. 3) Native peoples in North America made an effort to limit their hunting of northern fur seals in order to prevent depletion of seal populations. 4) Hunting by Native peoples in North America did not significantly reduce the northern fur seal population over the 800-year period studied.
answer: 2: Hunting by Native peoples in North America did not significantly reduce the northern fur seal population over the 800-year period studied.

question: In recent years, with the development of information technology and the evolution of the form of communication, a new phenomenon of deep fraud has emerged, which refers to processed video or other digital content generated by artificial intelligence technology. they produce seemingly real false images and sounds. An article in a well-known international journal of artificial intelligence pointed out in early 2019 that the artificial Intelligence Foundation raised $10 million to set up a tool that uses both human moderators and machine learning to identify fraudulent and malicious content such as deep fraud. The article also describes the efforts of a Dutch-based technology start-up to use adversarial machine learning as the main tool for detecting deep fraud. Which of the following options can be inferred? 1) We can solve the challenge of deep fraud by relying on the progress of technology. 2) The technology of deep fraud is often ahead of the latest detection technology. 3) Human beings cannot recognize the phenomenon of deep fraud like artificial intelligence. 4) Powerful artificial intelligence technology can be used to detect false or deceptive content.
answer: 4: Powerful artificial intelligence technology can be used to detect false or deceptive content.

question: When the summer vacation came, four people including father, mother, son and daughter went on a road trip. There are two people in the front row of the car (one as the driver) and two in the back row. Four people have different hobbies: music, sports, photography, calligraphy.The majors are also different:maths, history, logic and physics. It is known that: (1) the son studies physics, (2) the mother loves music, and (3) the photography enthusiast who studies logic sits diagonally with her daughter in two rows. If the son sits behind the driver, which of the following can be obtained? 1) Daughter is a driver 2) Son is a driver 3) Father is a driver 4) Mother is a driver

Increases in the level of high-density lipoprotein (HDL)in the human bloodstream lower bloodstream cholesterol levels by increasing the body' s capacity to rid itself of excess cholesterol. Levels of HDL in the bloodstream of some individuals are significantly increased by a program of regular exercise and weight reduction. Which of the following can be correctly inferred from the statements above? 1) Individuals who do not exercise regularly have a high risk of developing high levels of cholesterol in the bloodstream late in life. 2) A program of regular exercise and weight reduction lowers cholesterol levels in the bloodstream of some individuals. 3) Exercise and weight reduction are the most effective methods of lowering bloodstream cholesterol levels in humans. 4) Individuals who are underweight do not run any risk of developing high levels of cholesterol in the bloodstream.
answer: 1: A program of regular exercise and weight reduction lowers cholesterol levels in the bloodstream of some individuals.

question: Nutritionists: All medical research to date shows that drinking 3 cups or less of coffee a day is not harmful to the heart. Therefore, if you are a moderate coffee drinker, then you can enjoy coffee with confidence without worrying about coffee harming people's health. Which of the following statements most readily points out the flaw in the above argument? 1) The nutritionist's conclusions are only based on relevant research results and lack the support of clinical data 2) People who drink coffee often have greater psychological stress, and greater psychological stress itself is harmful to the heart 3) Coffee drinkers may eat other heart-bad foods while drinking coffee 4) Just because coffee is good for the heart doesn't mean it's good for the body
answer: 3: Just because coffee is good for the heart doesn't mean it's good for the body

question: Where there is smoke, there must be fire, So 1) Where there is no fire, there is no smoke 2) Where there is no smoke, there is no fire 3) Where there is smoke, there is not necessarily fire 4) Where there is no fire, there must be no smoke
answer: 1: Where there is no fire, there must be no smoke

question: Researchers in one country have reported that they have found meteorites from about 200 million years ago in strata in a certain area, and they are likely to be traces of flying debris when a giant meteorite hit what is now Quebec, Canada. The clay layer, which is about 5 centimeters thick, also contains high concentrations of elements such as iridium and platinum, which are 50 to 2000 times higher than those normally found on the earth's surface. In addition, this rock also contains special minerals in the strata at the end of the Baikui period. Since the strata also contain marine plankton fossils, it can be determined that the impact period was about 215 million years ago. Which of the followings, if true, can best support the above findings? 1) The rocks in this area were formed after the accumulation layer of the deep sea floor was exposed to the surface in ancient times 2) Mass extinction of ammonites and other species in the late Paleozoic Triassic (about 200 to 237 million years ago) 3) In ancient times, there were a number of meteorites hitting the earth 4) Elements such as iridium and platinum are unique to meteorites and are usually present in trace amounts on the surface
answer: 3: Elements such as iridium and platinum are unique to meteorites and are usually present in trace amounts on the surface

question: Unlike the lungs and the kidneys, the liver is an organ well suited for living-donor transplants to children because the portion of the liver which must be removed from a healthy adult to replace the diseased liver of a child will be regenerated in the healthy adult within a few months. Which of the following, if true, provides the most additional support for the conclusion drawn above? 1) Each lobe of the liver functions separately, and it is possible to extract a portion of one lobe without disrupting critical liver functions. 2) There are so few suitable donors that about one-half of the babies with liver disease born in the United States each year die before they can receive a liver transplant. 3) In removing the portion of liver for transplant there is danger of causing damage to the spleen of the donor, and that could necessitate the removal of the spleen. 4) There is less danger that a transplanted organ will be rejected when the organ donor is a, close relative of the recipient.
answer: 3: Each lobe of the liver functions separately, and it is possible to extract a portion of one lobe without disrupting critical liver functions.

question: At the student sports competition in a certain city, the champions of the 100-meter sprint for both men and women came from the sports class of the No. 1 Middle School, not the Municipal Sports School. Many parents are saying: The No. 1 Middle School has better training than the Municipal Sports School. Which of the following options can best refute the parents' conclusions? 1) Whether there is a sprint champion or not is not the only criterion to measure the quality of school training. 2) The number of champions of No. 1 Middle School in this game is much less than that of Municipal Sports School. 3) Because the teachers in No.1 Middle School are well paid, many teachers leave the Municipal Sports School to go to No.1 Middle School. 4) All the students in No. 1 Middle School are in accommodation, so they spend more time in school training than Municipal Sports School.
answer: 2: Whether there is a sprint champion or not is not the only criterion to measure the quality of school training.

question: British tourist John said to his guide Xiao Li, You are beautiful. Xiao Li modest answer, I am not beautiful. John paused, and looked at Xiao Li, saying that the whole body is beautiful, especially the eyes are beautiful. Based on the above conclusions, which of the following options is correct? 1) Lack of understanding of the conventional meaning of some idioms may lead to poor information in verbal communication 2) There are great differences between English and Chinese in grammatical structure 3) Even foreigners who speak Chinese well may make some jokes when they speak Chinese 4) In expressing meaning, oral language is less accurate than written language
answer: 1: Lack of understanding of the conventional meaning of some idioms may lead to poor information in verbal communication

question: Recently, in order to enliven the cultural atmosphere of the village, a village has launched a unique cultural activity of ploughing and reading, and there are a number of interested societies for villagers to choose from. It is known that the registration is as follows: (1) the villagers participated in at least one of the poetry club and calligraphy club; (2) if the villagers joined the poetry club, they did not join the choir; (3) Zhang joined the choir. After knowing the above situation, the village director concluded that Zhang also joined the fan club. Which of the following options, if true, can be a prerequisite for the village director to determine? 1) Those who do not join the fan club will not join the calligraphy club. 2) Zhang did not join the poetry club. 3) Zhang did not join the calligraphy club. 4) Those who joined the fan club also joined the calligraphy club.
answer: 4: Those who do not join the fan club will not join the calligraphy club.

question: Haze caused by fine particles is even more harmful to human health than sandstorms. Particles with a particle size of more than 10 microns will be blocked out of the human nose; particles with diameters between 2.5 microns and 10 microns can enter the upper respiratory tract, but some of them can be excreted through sputum, and will also be blocked by villi inside the nasal cavity, which is relatively less harmful to human health. Fine particles with a diameter of less than 2.5 microns will enter the bronchi, interfere with gas exchange in the lungs and cause diseases including asthma, bronchitis and cardiovascular diseases. These particles will also enter the blood, in which harmful gases, heavy metals and other dissolved in the blood, more harmful to human health. Which of the following is the main content of this text? 1) Different effects of particles with different particle sizes on human health 2) Fine particles in haze weather do great harm to human health 3) Heavy metals will dissolve in the blood and endanger human health 4) Pathogenic mechanism of particles of different size in disaster weather
answer: 2: Fine particles in haze weather do great harm to human health

question: In recent years, with the further enrollment expansion of colleges and universities, the number of college graduates is also increasing. There is a situation of oversupply in the social labor market, and the employment pressure is increasing greatly. The employment rate of college graduates in some areas is less than half. However, another phenomenon also appears. The employment situation of college students is generally better than that of undergraduates. Which of the following does not help explain the above phenomenon? 1) Undergraduates have strong theoretical knowledge but relatively weak practical ability. 2) College students are no smarter than undergraduates. 3) The employment expectation of college students is lower than that of undergraduates. 4) Society's demand for skilled talents is expanding.
answer: 4: College students are no smarter than undergraduates.

question: Councillor Miller opposes all proposals to raise taxes. Councillor Philopoulos supports increased funding for schools, which in this area are funded entirely by property taxes. It follows that Miller will oppose and Philopoulos will support Councillor Callari' s proposal to increase school funding by raising property taxes. Which one of the following exhibits flawed reasoning most similar to the flawed reasoning exhibited by the argument above? 1) Ed dislikes any food that is extremely sweet, but Bill likes most extremely sweet food. It follows that Ed will dislike these extremely sweet brownies but Bill will probably like them. 2) In the past, the citizens of Lake County have voted down every proposal to increase property taxes. It follows that citizens of Lake County will probably vote down the new proposed increase in property taxes. 3) Jane refuses to live downtown. Denise wants to rent a penthouse apartment. It follows that Jane will not rent one of the penthouse apartments in the Joliet Towers complex downtown but Denise will rent one of those apartments. 4) Tara finds Ms. Burke's English class, which has paper assignments but no exams, easier than Mr. Kent's English class, which has exams but no paper assignments. It follows that Tara finds it easier to write a paper than to take an exam.
answer: 3: Jane refuses to live downtown. Denise wants to rent a penthouse apartment. It follows that Jane will not rent one of the penthouse apartments in the Joliet Towers complex downtown but Denise will rent one of those apartments.

question: Generations of European-history students have been taught that a political assassination caused the First World War. Without some qualification, however, this teaching is bound to mislead, since the war would not have happened without the treaties and alliances that were already in effect and the military force that was already amassed. These were the deeper causes of the war, whereas the assassination was a cause only in a trivial sense. It was like the individual spark that happens to ignite a conflagration that was, in the prevailing conditions, inevitable. Which one of the following most accurately restates the main point of the passage? 1) Though the statement that the assassination caused the war is true, the term causemore fundamentally applies to the conditions that made it possible for that event to start the war. 2) Although the conditions prevailing at the time the war started made war inevitable, if the war had not been triggered by the assassination it would not have taken the course with which students of history are familiar. 3) The war was destined to happen, since the course of history up to that point could not have been altered. 4) The assassination did not cause the war, since the assassination was only the last in a chain of events leading up to the war, each of which had equal claim to being called its cause.
answer: 1: Though the statement that the assassination caused the war is true, the term causemore fundamentally applies to the conditions that made it possible for that event to start the war.

question: All zebras have stripes, and the most widespread subspecies has the best-defined stripes. The stripes must ttherefore be of importance to the species. Since among these grassland grazers the stripes can hardly function as camouflage, they must serve as some sort of signal for other zebras. Which one of the following, if true, most strongly supports the conclusion regarding a signaling function? 1) Zebras react much faster to moving shapes that have stripes than they do to moving shapes that are otherwise identical but lack stripes. 2) The subspecies of zebras with the best-defined stripes is also characterized by exceptional size and vigor. 3) In certain tall grasses zebras can be harder to spot than grazing animals with a coat of uniform color. 4) A visual signal transmitted among the members of a species can consist of a temporary change of color perceptible to other members of the species.
answer: 1: Zebras react much faster to moving shapes that have stripes than they do to moving shapes that are otherwise identical but lack stripes.

question: Even the earliest known species of land animals, known from fossils dating from the late Silurian period, 400 million years ago, show highly evolved adaptations to life on land. Since neither aquatic nor amphibious animals exhibit these adaptations, early species of land animals must have evolved very rapidly after leaving an aquatic environment. Which one of the following is an assumption on which the argument depends? 1) Known fossils of early land animals include fossils of animals that lived relatively soon after the first emergence of land animals. 2) Fossils from the late Silurian period represent only a small number of the animal species that were alive at that time. 3) No plants were established on land before the late Silurian period. 4) No present-day species of aquatic animal is descended from a species of animal that once lived on land.
answer: 1: Known fossils of early land animals include fossils of animals that lived relatively soon after the first emergence of land animals.

question: The demand for used cars has risen dramatically in Germany in recent years. Most of this demand is generated by former East Germans who cannot yet afford new cars and for whom cars were generally unavailable prior to unification. This demand has outstripped supply and thus has exerted an upward pressure on the prices of used cars. Consequently, an increasing number of former West Germans, in order to take advantage of the improved market, will be selling the cars they have owned for several years. Hence, the German new-car market will most likely improve soon as well. Which one of the following, if true, would most help to support the conclusion about the German new-car market? 1) Most Germans own very few cars in the course of their lives. 2) In most European countries, the sale of a used car is subject to less tax than is the sale of a new car. 3) The demand for old cars in former West Germany is greater than the demand for new cars in former East Germany. 4) Most former West Germans purchase new cars once they sell their used cars.
answer: 3: Most former West Germans purchase new cars once they sell their used cars.

question: The researchers selected 16 11-month-old children, eight of whom came from monolingual families and eight from Spanish-speaking, English-speaking families. Each child listens to an audio that is about 18 minutes long, both in English and Spanish. Using brain magnetic records, the researchers found that in the executive regions of the brain, bilingual families, older children, responded more strongly to verbal vocal stimuli than children from monolingual families. This suggests that bilingualism has long had an effect on brain activity Which of the following options , if true, would best support the above view? 1) Children growing up in bilingual families can master bilingualism without their parents' deliberate teaching 2) Bilingual children's perception of foreign language sound at 11 months old was significantly stronger than that at 6 months old 3) Previous human brain studies have shown that adults with bilingual ability have more active executive function 4) In contrast, Spanish has more obvious sound stimulation to the brain than English
answer: 2: Children growing up in bilingual families can master bilingualism without their parents' deliberate teaching

question: Several excellent candidates have been proposed for the presidency of United Wire, and each candidate would bring to the job different talents and experience. If the others are compared with Jones, however, it will be apparent that none of them has her unique set of qualifications. Jones, ttherefore, is best qualified to be the new president of United Wire. The argument is vulnerable to criticism on the ground that it 1) refutes a distorted version of an opposing position 2) seeks to distinguish one member of a group on the basis of something that applies to all 3) supports a universal claim on the basis of a single example 4) uses flattery to win over those who hold an opposing position
answer: 2: seeks to distinguish one member of a group on the basis of something that applies to all

question: When a planetary system forms, the chances that a planet capable of supporting life will be formed are high. The chances that a large planet the size of Jupiter or Saturn will be formed, however, are low. Without Jupiter and Saturn, whose gravitational forces have prevented Earth from being frequently struck by large comets, intelligent life would never have arisen on Earth. Since planetary systems are unlikely to contain any large planets, the chances that intelligent life will emerge on a planet are, ttherefore, low. Knowing which one of the following would be most useful in evaluating the argument? 1) whether all planetary systems are formed from similar amounts of matter 2) how likely it is that planetary systems containing large planets will also contain planets the size of Earth 3) whether large comets could be deflected by only one large planet rather than by two 4) how high the chances are that planetary systems will contain many large comets
answer: 3: how high the chances are that planetary systems will contain many large comets

question: Coffee shop owner: A large number of customers will pay at least the fair market value for a cup of coffee, even if there is no formal charge. Some will pay more than this out of appreciation of the trust that is placed in them. And our total number of customers is likely to increase. We could ttherefore improve our net cash flow by implementing an honor system in which customers pay what they wish for coffee by depositing money in a can. Manager: We're likely to lose money on this plan. Many customers would cheat the system, paying a very small sum or nothing at all. which of the following, if true, would best support the owner's plan, in light of the manager's concern? 1) The new system, if implemented, would increase the number of customers. 2) By roasting its own coffee, the shop has managed to reduce the difficulties (and cost) of maintaining an inventory of freshly roasted coffee. 3) The shop makes a substantial profit from pastries and other food bought by the coffee drinkers. 4) No other coffee shop in the area has such a system.
answer: 1: The shop makes a substantial profit from pastries and other food bought by the coffee drinkers.

question: Mourdet Winery: Danville Winery' s new wine was introduced to compete with our most popular wine, which is sold in a distinctive tall, black bottle. Danville uses a similar bottle. Thus, it is likely that many customers intending to buy our wine will mistakenly buy theirs instead. Danville Winery: Not so. The two bottles can be readily distinguished: the label on ours, but not on theirs, is gold colored. Which of the following, if true, most undermines Danville Winery's response? 1) It is common for occasional purchasers to buy a bottle of wine on the basis of a general impression of the most obvious feature of the bottle. 2) Gold is the background color on the label of many of the wines produced by Danville Winery. 3) When the bottles are viewed side by side, Danville Winery's bottle is perceptibly taller than Mourdet Winery's. 4) Danville Winery, unlike Mourdet Winery, displays its wine's label prominently in advertisements.
answer: 4: It is common for occasional purchasers to buy a bottle of wine on the basis of a general impression of the most obvious feature of the bottle.

question: Another important factor contributing to the slow growth of anthropology is that Europeans have only come to realize that under the cover of all these differences, they can share basic humanity with people anywhere. Societies that do not share basic cultural values with Europeans are labeled uncivilized or barbaric. It was not until the mid-18 th century that a considerable number of Europeans began to think that the behavior of such people was completely related to their understanding of themselves. An era has come when people are increasingly trying to explain things according to natural law, sceptical about traditional interpretations based on authoritative texts, and increasingly interested in human diversity. Which of the following is the best understanding of human diversity? 1) Differences in folk customs and identification with uncivilized or barbaric nations 2) The different origins of human beings and people's unique views on different nations and different cultures 3) The cultural differences of different nationalities and their differences in age, gender, personality, etc 4) Different nationalities have differences in cultural values and their unique behaviors
answer: 4: Different nationalities have differences in cultural values and their unique behaviors

question: Amateur gardeners who plant based on the phases of the moon tend to get better results than those who do not. This seems surprising since the phases of the moon do not affect how plants grow. An alternative practice often found among amateur gardeners is to plant during the first warm spell of spring, which leads to problems when a frost follows. So, amateur gardeners who use the phases of the moon are less likely to lose plants to a frost. The argument requires assuming which one of the following? 1) The phases of the moon affect whether a frost follows the first warm spell of spring. 2) Amateur gardeners cannot improve their results unless they understand why their methods work as they do. 3) Using the phases of the moon usually leads amateur gardeners to plant later in the spring than those planting at the first warm spell. 4) Amateur gardeners who use the phases of the moon tend to plant different types of plants than do other amateur gardeners.
answer: 4: Using the phases of the moon usually leads amateur gardeners to plant later in the spring than those planting at the first warm spell.

question: Although the number of large artificial satellites orbiting the Earth is small compared to the number of small pieces of debris in orbit, the large satellites interfere more seriously with telescope observations because of the strong reflections they produce. Because many of those large satellites have ceased to function, the proposal has recently been made to eliminate interference from nonfunctioning satellites by exploding them in space. This proposal, however, is ill conceived, since __. Which of the following most logically completes the argument below? 1) for satellites that have ceased to function, repairing them while they are in orbit would be prohibitively expensive 2) the only way to make telescope observations without any interference from debris in orbit is to use telescopes launched into extremely high orbits around the Earth 3) a greatly increased number of small particles in Earth's orbit would result in a blanket of reflections that would make certain valuable telescope observations impossible 4) there are no known previous instances of satellites' having been exploded on purpose
answer: 4: a greatly increased number of small particles in Earth's orbit would result in a blanket of reflections that would make certain valuable telescope observations impossible

question: Phobia is an irrational, inappropriate fear of an object or environment. Once faced with such an object or environment, people with phobias develop an extreme sense of fear, even though there is no danger at the time. According to the above definition, which of the following belongs to phobia? 1) After watching the horror movie the Midnight Killer, Xiao Li always thought of the horror scenes in the movie and couldn't sleep well for several days in a row 2) After supper, Ms. Chen was walking in the community when a cat suddenly sprang out of the grass, making her scream and run home 3) When 21-year-old A had an argument with his brother when she was young, her father picked up a sharpened piece of bamboo and threw it at her. although he missed it, he was still very scared when he thought of the sharp piece of bamboo. When he saw or even thought of sharp objects, he was very nervous, broke out in a cold sweat and trembled all over his body 4) Xiao Sun just got his driver's license and drove Xiao Ming home. Xiao Ming was about to get off on the way, because she was worried about Xiao Sun's driving skills and had been under the mental pressure of being afraid of an accident since she got on the car
answer: 2: When 21-year-old A had an argument with his brother when she was young, her father picked up a sharpened piece of bamboo and threw it at her. although he missed it, he was still very scared when he thought of the sharp piece of bamboo. When he saw or even thought of sharp objects, he was very nervous, broke out in a cold sweat and trembled all over his body

question: A street comprehensive management committee has a total of 6 members: F, G, H, I, M and P. Each of these members shall serve as a member of at least one of the three sub-committees under the Comprehensive Management Committee. Each sub-committee consists of three different members. The known information is as follows: one of the six members serves as a member of three subcommittees. F is not a member of the same subcommittee as G. H is not a member of the same subcommittee as I. Which of the following options may be true? 1) I serve on the subcommittee, there is P. 2) F serves as a member of the three sub-committees. 3) G serves as a member of the three sub-committees. 4) H serves as a member of the three sub-committees.
answer: 4: I serve on the subcommittee, there is P.

question: Scientist: A number of errors can plague a data-collection process. Since examining the collected data enables researchers to detect many of these errors, it is standard practice for researchers to correct collected data. However, in my field, there is a striking tendency for such corrections to favor Jones' s theory; that is, the majority of corrections result in the corrected data' s being closer than the uncorrected data to what Jones' s theory predicts. Which one of the following, if true, most helps to explain the tendency of corrections in the scientist's field to favor Jones 's theory? 1) Researchers normally give data that is in line with a theory the same weight as data that conflicts with that theory when they are determining whether to accept that theory. 2) Researchers in the scientist's field have formulated several other theories that attempt to explain the same range of phenomena that Jones's theory attempts to explain. 3) Researchers in the scientist's field give data that conflicts with Jones 's theory greater scrutiny than they give data that is in line with Jones's theory. 4) Even if researchers fail to detect errors in a data-collection process when they examine the data that they collected, that does not guarantee that no such errors exist.
answer: 4: Researchers in the scientist's field give data that conflicts with Jones 's theory greater scrutiny than they give data that is in line with Jones's theory.

question: A university psychology department received a large donation from a textbook company after agreeing to use one of the company' s books for a large introductory course. The department chair admitted that the department would not have received the donation if it used another company' s textbook, but insisted that the book was chosen solely for academic reasons. As proof, she noted that the department' s textbook committee had given that textbook its highest rating. Which one of the following, if true, most weakens the case for the department chair's position? 1) The textbook company does not routinely make donations to academic departments that use its books. 2) The department has a long-standing policy of using only textbooks that receive the committee's highest rating. 3) In the previous year, a different textbook from the same company was used in the introductory course. 4) The members of the textbook committee were favorably influenced toward the textbook by the prospect of their department receiving a large donation.
answer: 2: The members of the textbook committee were favorably influenced toward the textbook by the prospect of their department receiving a large donation.

question: Paleontologists recently discovered teeth from several woolly mammoths on an isolated Arctic island where no mammoth fossils had previously been found. The teeth were 25 percent smaller on average than adult mammoth teeth that have been found elsewhere, but they are clearly adult mammoth teeth. Ttherefore, provided that the teeth are representative of their respective populations, woolly mammoths that lived on the island were smaller on average than those that lived elsewhere. Which one of the following, if assumed, would allow the conclusion to be properly drawn? 1) Neither tooth size nor overall body size is completely uniform among adult members of most species, including woolly mammoths. 2) The tooth wear that naturally occurs in many animals over the course of their adult years did not result in a significant change in tooth size among adult woolly mammoths as they aged. 3) Woolly mammoths of the kind that lived on the island had the same number and variety of teeth as mammoths that lived elsewhere had. 4) Tooth size among adult woolly mammoths was always directly proportional to the overall size of those mammoths.
answer: 3: Tooth size among adult woolly mammoths was always directly proportional to the overall size of those mammoths.

question: In 1984, George W. Bush said that he would like to be a good president. Bush and Dan. Quail's running mate ran for president of the United States when people attacked Him, saying his family had helped him squeeze into Indiana's National Guard to avoid military service and combat in Vietnam.In response, Bush retorted, Dan. Quail, who served in the National Guard and had a vacancy in his unit, was under fire from patriotic men.....and he didn't go to Vietnam, but his team wasn't sent there. There are some facts that no one can erase. He didn't flee to Canada, he didn't burn his card, he didn't burn the American flag! Which of the following options is most similar to Bush's? 1) A graduate student said to his supervisor: Students with excellent academic performance study very hard. If you want me to study hard, the best way is to arbitrate all my courses. 2) Some company uses starch to add brown sugar to make so-called nutrition heighten agent , be cheated very numerous.  The business administration had to shut it down because it was fake.  The company's chairman, Zhen Zhen, resigned to fight the seizure, saying: I didn't kill anyone.  You don't believe me. I'll show you what I eat now, and I'll do my job and fill my stomach.   3) You say all swans are white is wrong, because black swans have long been found in Australia 4) One company manager said, There used to be an old saying that money is the dirtiest relationship.  In fact, in a sense, money is the purest relationship, and human relations are the most complicated. I can't tell what dirty things are inside.  So I don't borrow money from my friends, and I never do business with them.
answer: 1: Some company uses starch to add brown sugar to make so-called nutrition heighten agent , be cheated very numerous.  The business administration had to shut it down because it was fake.  The company's chairman, Zhen Zhen, resigned to fight the seizure, saying: I didn't kill anyone.  You don't believe me. I'll show you what I eat now, and I'll do my job and fill my stomach.

question: Mark: To convey an understanding of past events, a historian should try to capture what it was like to experience those events. For instance, a foot soldier in the Battle of Waterloo knew through direct experience what the battle was like, and it is this kind of knowledge that the historian must capture. Carla: But how do you go about choosing whose perspective is the valid one? Is the foot soldier' s perspective more valid than that of a general? Should it be a French or an English soldier? Your approach would generate a biased version of history, and to avoid that, historians must stick to general and objective characterizations of the past. Carla does which one of the following in disputing Mark's position? 1) questions Mark's presupposition that one person can understand another's feelings 2) argues that the selection involved in carrying out Mark's proposal would distort the result 3) questions whether Mark accurately describes the kind of historical writing he deplores 4) gives reason to believe that Mark's recommendation is motivated by his professional self-interest
answer: 4: argues that the selection involved in carrying out Mark's proposal would distort the result

question: All metals conduct electricity. Iron conducts electricity, so iron is a metal. Which of the following is most similar to the above reasoning structure? 1) All metals conduct electricity. Copper is a metal, so copper conducts electricity. 2) All birds are not plants. Sparrows are birds, so sparrows are not plants. 3) All birds are not plants. Man is an animal, so man is a bird. 4) The associate professor is an intellectual. The researcher is not an associate professor, so the researcher is not an intellectual.
answer: 4: All birds are not plants. Man is an animal, so man is a bird.

question: Social critic: One of the most important ways in which a society socializes children is by making them feel ashamed of their immoral behavior. But in many people this shame results in deep feelings of guilt and selfloathing that can be a severe hardship. Thus, moral socialization has had a net effect of increasing the total amount of suffering. The social critic's argument is most vulnerable to criticism on the grounds that it 1) fails to address adequately the possibility that one phenomenon may causally contribute to the occurrence of another, even though the two phenomena do not always occur together 2) presumes, without providing justification, that if many people have a negative psychological reaction to a phenomenon, then no one can have a positive reaction to that phenomenon 3) presumes, without providing justification, that a phenomenon that supposedly increases the total amount of suffering in a society should ttherefore be changed or eliminated, regardless of its beneficial consequences 4) takes for granted that a behavior that sometimes leads to a certain phenomenon cannot also significantly reduce the overall occurrence of that phenomenon
answer: 4: takes for granted that a behavior that sometimes leads to a certain phenomenon cannot also significantly reduce the overall occurrence of that phenomenon

question: Historian: The only evidence we have for claims about the past exists in the present. How things actually occurred is beyond our knowledge. Historians construct coherent stories that explain the available evidence and why the present is as it is. Such stories about the past, however, do not need to be true to be good history; they need only explain the evidence about the past and what we know about the present better than do rival accounts. Which one of the following judgments conforms most closely to the historian's position? 1) It is not possible to write a good history of the 1857 War of Independence without studying rival accounts. 2) It is likely that the 1857 War of Independence did not actually occur in the way we think it did. 3) An account of the 1857 War of Independence that is true is better as history than one that is not true but better explains the evidence. 4) It is not necessary to know what actually occurred during the 1857 War of Independence to write a good history of it.
answer: 1: It is not necessary to know what actually occurred during the 1857 War of Independence to write a good history of it.

question: Tania: A good art critic is not fair in the ordinary sense; it is only about things that do not interest one that one can give a truly unbiased opinion. Since art is a passion, good criticism of art cannot be separated from emotion. Monique: Art is not simply a passion. The best art critics passionately engage with the artwork, but render their criticism only after shedding all of their biases and consulting general principles of aesthetics. The dialogue most strongly supports the claim that Tania and Monique disagree about whether 1) good art criticism is sometimes unbiased 2) art is not simply a passion 3) fairness generally requires minimizing the influence of bias 4) art critics should not feel emotion toward artworks
answer: 3: good art criticism is sometimes unbiased

question: Emmons, an American shooter, is an unlucky guy on the field. In the final of the men's rifle at the 2004 Athens Olympic Games, he hit the last bullet on someone else's target with a three-point lead over his opponent, losing his upcoming medal. However, he was comforted by the beautiful Czech girl Katarina and finally won love. This is really a saying: if the game is frustrated, then the love field is proud. If this proverb is true, which of the following options must be false? 1) Both the game and the love field are proud. 2) Both the game and the love field are frustrated. 3) Only when you are frustrated on the game will you be happy in love field. 4) Only when you are frustrated on the love field will you be happy in game.
answer: 2: Both the game and the love field are frustrated.

question: If the county continues to collect residential trash at current levels, landfills will soon be overflowing and parkland will need to be used in order to create more space. Charging each household a fee for each pound of trash it puts out for collection will induce residents to reduce the amount of trash they create; this charge will ttherefore protect the remaining county parkland. Which of the following is an assumption made in drawing the conclusion above? 1) The beauty of county parkland is an important issue for most of the county's residents. 2) The collection fee will not induce residents to dump their trash in the parklands illegally. 3) Residents will reduce the amount of trash they put out for collection by reducing the number of products they buy. 4) The collection fee will not significantly affect the purchasing power of most residents, even if their households do not reduce the amount of trash they put out.
answer: 4: The collection fee will not induce residents to dump their trash in the parklands illegally.

question: An antidote for chicken pox has been developed, but researchers warn that its widespread use could be dangerous, despite the fact that this drug has no serious side effects and is currently very effective at limiting the duration and severity of chicken pox. Which one of the following, if true, helps most to reconcile the apparent discrepancy indicated above? 1) When misused by taking larger-than-prescribed doses, the drug can be fatal. 2) The drug is extremely expensive and would be difficult to make widely available. 3) The drug has to be administered several times a day, so patient compliance is likely to be low. 4) Use of the drug contributes to the development of deadlier forms of chicken pox that are resistant to the drug.
answer: 4: Use of the drug contributes to the development of deadlier forms of chicken pox that are resistant to the drug.

question: In a plastic greenhouse, there are six rectangular vegetable ponds of the same size, arranged in order from left to right: numbers 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 and 6. And No. 1 is not adjacent to No. 6. Six kinds of vegetables need to be planted in the greenhouse. Q, L, H, X, S and Y. Only one of them can be planted in each vegetable pond. The planting arrangement must meet the following conditions: Q is planted in a vegetable pond on the left side of H. X is planted in the No. 1 or No. 6 vegetable pond. Y or S is planted in the No. 3 vegetable pond. L is planted next to the right side of S. Which of the following options is a qualified planting arrangement? 1) 1 planting L,2 planting S,3 planting Y,4 planting Q,5,planting H,6 planting X. 2) 1 planting Y,2 planting Q,3 planting S,4 planting L,5,planting H,6 planting X. 3) 1 planting H,2 planting Q,3 planting Y,4 planting S,5,planting L,6 planting X. 4) 1 planting X,2 planting Y,3 planting Q,4 planting S,5,planting L,6 planting H.
answer: 1: 1 planting Y,2 planting Q,3 planting S,4 planting L,5,planting H,6 planting X.

question: The distinction between behavioral offenses and consequential offenses is to determine the completed and attempted crimes. Behavioral offenses refer to only performing the behavior described in the constitutive elements, without the occurrence of material harmful results to constitute an accomplished crime. It requires that the behavior of the perpetrator has a certain material harmful result before it can constitute a completed crime. According to the above definition, which of the followings of completed crimes are behavioral offenses? 1) Theft refers to the act of stealing a large amount of public and private properties or multiple thefts of public and private properties for the purpose of illegal possession. 2) Crime of escape refers to the behavior of criminals and criminal suspects detained in accordance with the law escaping from the custody and supervision of judicial organs. 3) Robbery refers to the act of forcibly stealing public and private property by violence, coercion or other methods for the purpose of illegal possession. 4) Intentional homicide refers to the act of deliberately and illegally depriving others' lives.
answer: 3: Intentional homicide refers to the act of deliberately and illegally depriving others' lives.

question: Financing refers to the monetary transaction means or acquisition of assets to pay more than the purchase price of cash, and the monetary means used to raise funds According to the above definition, which of the following options is not financing? 1) Mr. Zhang intends to put a restaurant down, not enough money to find a friend Mr. Li borrowed 500,000, agreed to two years even the principal and interest paid off 2) A unit is prepared to use an idle piece of land to solve the accommodation of workers, but lack of 30 million funds, some people proposed to borrow money from employees, and pay the appropriate profits after the installment 3) A company plans to develop a new product to lend money to a bank 4) Xiao Zhang in order to facilitate commuting, take out their 80,000 yuan savings, find parents borrowed 30,000 yuan, bought a car
answer: 1: Xiao Zhang in order to facilitate commuting, take out their 80,000 yuan savings, find parents borrowed 30,000 yuan, bought a car

question: From 250 to 800 AD, the Mayan civilization was still very developed, the city prospered, and the crop harvest was also very gratifying. Climate records show that the precipitation in the Maya region during this period was relatively high. After that, the Mayan civilization began to decline. From about 820 AD for 95 consecutive years, the region began to experience intermittent droughts, and droughts in some places even lasted for decades. Many experts believe that climate change in the 9th century may be the cause of the demise of the Mayan civilization.
